column2: DETROIT, Nov. 3. The business men of Detroit, like those of their sister cities, have aroused to a full appreciation of the gravity of the political crisis which is upon us, and to-day a paper has been circulated and extensively signed by our wholesale merchants, pledging themselves to close their establishments on election day, and give their time to personal efforts for the success of the Republican cause.

The spectacle preceded by the Second Brigade Boys in Blue, under command of Gen. Lloyd Aspinwall, has never been equaled in its way in NewYork. The brigade consisted of five full regiments of ten companies each, beside three or four independent battalions and companies, and not a boy could be found anywhere in the ranks, every torch there represented a voter who will deposit his paper bullet for Hayes and Wheeler next ...

The political outlook in this city and county grows brigher for the Republicans every day. Three weeks ago the incessant brag and bluster of the Tildenites had produced a discouraging effect upon the Republicans, but that has all passed off, and the supporters of Hayes are now closing ranks with firm hearts and steady hands.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. This was the third and last day of the Fall running meeting of the National Jockey Club. The weather was cold and partly cloudy, with a chilly north-west wind blowing. A rain-storm at an early hour in the morning made the track a little heavy. The attendance was the smallest during the meeting.

This district belongs to the Republicans; it has been represented by Republicans, and it ought to continue to be. Major Corsa should receive the cordial support of his party. He is personally popular; and his record, known to all his constituency, entitles him to a solid majority over his Democratic opponent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. Four companies of the Fourth Artillery arrived here this morning, direct from South Carolina, and are now quartered at the Arsenal. They number two hundred and fifty men, are under the command of Capt. Loder, and come here in pursuance of orders from Gen. Sherman. None of the officers of Gen. Sherman's staff knew of their coming, and profess ignorance of their future movements.

The gold yield of California, this year will probably be about $20,000,000, or as much as it was in 1875. Of this, two-thirds may come from placer claims, and the remainder from quartz. The greater part of the placer gold is obtained by hydraulic claims in the channels of dead rivers, with deposits of auriferous gravel several hundred feet deep and a quarter or a half-mile wide.

LONDON, Nov. 21. A dispatch to Reuter's Telegram Company from St. Petersburg says a dispatch of Prince Gortschakoff to Count Schouvaloff, the Russian Ambassador at London, dated Nov. 7, is published. The Prince expresses satisfaction that Lord Derby recognized, in his dispatch of Oct. 30 to Lord Loftus, the British Ambassador at St. Petersburg, (which was sent for transmission to Prince Gortschakoff,) the efforts of the Russian Cabinet to co-operate with England.

To PRESERVE EGGS.--I.--Mix together in a tub or vessel one bushel of quick lime, two pounds of salt, one-half pound cream of tartar, with as much water as will reduce the compostion to a consistence to float an egg, then keep the eggs therein. This will preserve them perfect for two years at least-- FRANCES.

In the village communities of Great Russia the family still exists in its more primitive type. Property is undivided among the children or brothers who live together; each man has an equal right to its fruits. Paternal authority is supreme. The married son remains subject to his father till he has a son of his own grown up, or till he succeeds to the headship of the family.

The annual report of the Librarian of Congress, submitted to-day to the Joint Committee on the Library, shows that the number of bound books in the library at the present time is 311,097, and of pamphlets, 100,000. NORFOLK, Jan. 17. On the night of Jan. 1, John W. Tatem, a watchman on board the United States steamer Canandaigua which was lying near the Navy-yard, shot and mortally wounded Michael Joyce, a workman in the Navy-yard, who was attempting, to steal old iron and copper pipes from that ship.

The Democrats in the House are indignant that the President, in the exercise of the discretionary authority with which he is invested, has stationed handful of troops at Washington. Ninety-nine of the members carry their indignation so far that they are willing to override the Constitution, and to prescribe to the President in a matter which is absolutely within his jurisdiction.

HARRISBURG, Jan. 17. A caucus of the Republican members of the Legislature was held here this morning. The committee of three Senators and four Representatives, including the Speakers of the two Houses who, were appointed last week to consider the propriety of introducing a bill into the Legislature to place the Militia of the State upon a war footing, it was expected would make its report tonight.

The fourth annual meeting of the New-York Training School for Nurses was held yesterday afternoon, in Grace Hall, Fourteenth street, Rev. Dr. Henry S. Potter, of Grace Church, presiding, and Mr. Chandler Robbins acting as Secretary.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. The joint committee of the two houses for arranging a method of counting the Electoral vote agreed, to-night, upon a scheme which has been stated in the form of a bill, and which will be presented in both houses to-morrow, unless the action should be reconsidered in the morning, which is not probable.

BUCHAREST, Jan. 17.--Safvet Pasha, the Turkish Minister of Foreign Affairs, has ordered the Turkish commandant at Silistria to punish the Bashi-Bazouks who crossed the Danube on the night of the 8th inst and plundered a Roumanian outpost and killed two Roumanian soldiers.

The Brooklyn Board of Aldermen, after transacting some routine business, made their weekly attempt to break the dead-lock, which has existed since the first meeting of the board this year, by effecting a permanent organization.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. The United States Treasurer will send to the different Sub-Treasurers throughout the country photographic copies of the counterfeit 81,000 note recently discovered, and also a photographic copy of the genuine note. The counterfeit note in possession of the department has the appearance of having been oiled.

The Senate resumed its session at 10 o'clock A.M., with but few Senators present. In reply to a question of Mr. Withers, of Virginia, the President pro tem, said: "The House will be ready to receive the Senate for the purpose of resuming the count of the Electoral vote at 11 o'clock."

ALBANY, Feb. 19. Senator Gerard's resolution for an amendment to the Constitution consolidating the Superior and Common Pleas Courts of the City of New-York with the Supreme Court, was ordered to a third reading, with an amendment giving to the Legislature power to equalize the salaries of all the Supreme Court Judges in the City of New-York during their present terms of office.

The trial of the suit of Owen W. Brennan against the Mayor, c., was begun before Judge Lawrence and a jury, in Part II. of the Supreme Court, yesterday. A dispatch from St. Petesburg to Reuter's Telegram Company says the statement contained in a dispatch to the Times last Tuesday that at an extraordinary council of the Ministers hold on Monday it was decided to demobilize the Russian Army when peace is signed between the Porte and Servia and Montenegro, is absolutely untrue. No such council was held.

It is not often given to a scientific society to amuse the outer world; but the Astronomical Society seems in the way to achieve this distinction. It has recently, in the person of one of its fellows, enunciated a theory as irrefutable, by direct evidence, as the famous, though scarcely scientific, proposition that the moon is made of green cheese.

PARIS, March 2.--The Memorial Diplomatique corroborates the report that England has suggested to Russia that the Porte be allowed a respite to carry into effect the promised reforms. So far the pourparlers on this proposition have been fruitless, becuase Russia insists that England shall enter into some engagement respecting the course to be followed at a future date, an undertaking which England declines to give.

LONDON, March 2.--The Post reviews the events connected with the Presidential question in the United States; praises the moderation of the majority of the Democratic Party, as compared with the happily-defeated tactics of the filibustering section, and concludes: We fear President Hayes' authority will be seriously diminished by she means adopted to secure his return.

LIVERPOOL, March 2.--A dispatch to the Courier from London says: "Hon. Mrs. Norton, the poetess and nevelist, was merried yesterday to Sir William Stirling Maxwell, Bart., Member of Parliament for perthshire. The ceremony was performed at the bride's residence. There are no particularly new features of interest relating to market supplies. Everything of an edible character is plentiful, and prices are generally low. Fish and eggs are abundant. Meat, as is usual in the Lenten season, is in light demand, but, with a moderate supply, prices are maintained. Batter is plentiful, and the rates for it are gradually falling to the standard which prevailed before the war.

In the Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday, the application of the Park Department for the sum of $90,000 to build a bridge over the Harlem River, at the end of Madison avenue, was called up by Controller Kelly.

The Conterence of the Methodist Episcopal Church having jurisdicton in this City in 1830 estalhished a mission in Harlem, including all the secreties of the denomination from Bowery Village to Harlem Bridge, and in 1831, through the exertions of Rev. Richard Seaman, a class was established in Yorkville which afterward developed into the Eighty sixth-street Methodist Church.

The Boston Traveller says: "A Young man vigorous enough to pass master as a soldier, called at a house in Princeton street, East Boston, and asked for something to eat. The lady of the house brought him some newly-baked bread and cheese and coffee, and pointed to a sent in the yard, where he might sit and eat and drink what she had given him.

The steamer Newport of the New-York and Fali River Line, burst her main steam pipe at 5 o'clock this morning when off Point Judith. No one was hurt. The steamer was towed back to Newport by the steamer Old Colony, where she will be reparied, and will probablyleave to-night.

At midnight the Legislative, Executive and Judicial, sundry civil and army appropriation bills were not agreed upon by the conference committees. In the Legislative bill the point upon which the conference disagreed is the reduction of the President's salary.

A meeting of the National Executive Committee of the Union League of America was held to-day at Willard's Hotel, at which important business was transacted. The following-named gentlemen were among those present: Gen. Daniel Uilman, of New-York, Chairman; Samuel A. MacAlister of Delaware, Secretary; Hon. Mark Brewer and C. F. Kimball, of Michigan, Hon. George H. Harlow, of Illinois, Charles W. Godard; W. V. Alexander and L. A. Lecomtes,

The newly-built frigate Trenton, which bad been in sailing condition for several days previous, was peremptorily ordered to sea yesterday afternoon. She will proceed to the Mediterranean station, where she will be used as the flag-ship of Rear Admiral Worden, of Monitor fame. Tile Trenton is to steam directly to Gibraltar, at which port Admiral Worden is expected to board her.

Capt. Thomas M. Daly, of Company K, Twenty-second Regiment, was entertained at a banquet by the members of his company last Thursday night. The left ring of the Thirty-second Regiment, Companies A, C, H, and E, had a drill last Wednesday evening, equalizing in five companies of 12 files front. .

The event of the day is the death of Gen. Changarnier, who breathed his last on Wednesday evening. His illness was a short one, and promised to he slight, but when one has arrived at the age of 81 there is no telling what the result of a malady may be. No man could have borne the burden of 80 odd years more gaily than Changarnier.

ALLERTON.--Saturday, March 3, DAVID ALLERTON, in the 59th year of his age. Funeral Tuesday, march 6, at 1 o'clock from his late residence. East Chester. Train leaves Grand Central Depot for Mount Vernon, New-Haven Railroad, at 12 m. BESANT.--On Friday March 2, at the Century Club, JOSEPH A. BESANT, Superintendent of the club, aged 45 , of paeumonia.

The President today had a very interesting conversation with Gen. Gordon on South Carolina affairs. Gen. Gordon appealed to him to take the same action with regard to South Carolina as he had in Louisiana. The President said that he had not yet made up his mind concerning South Carolina;

The horses of the street railroad companies have during the past Winter been more completely exempt from daugerous discases than for many previous seasons, notwithstanding the severity of the weather, the numerous storms. the ice and snow in the streets, and, worse than all, the abundant slush caused by the practice of salling the tracks.

The tall house lowers grimly, Deformed by smoke and rain And the bleared sunshine dimly Blinks on the window-pane. Though sore and numb her fingers, And slowly fades the light, The girl nor rests nor lingers, But sews from morn till night.

Advices received here from the northern States of Mexico by the steam-ship Colima last Tuesday, and a telegram from the City of Mexico received on the preceding day announcing the installation of Gen. Diaz as President of Mexico, have induced Iglesias to decide upon returning home.

James Wilson was committed to the Tombs for trial in default of $1,000 ball, by Justice Wandell, at the Essex Market Police Court, for having attempted, yesterday afternoon, to force an entrance to the apartments of James Richardson, on the third floor of No. 108 Delancey-street, with the intention of robbery.

Rev. W. H. Leavell, of the Stanton-street Baptist Church of this City, announces his intention to resign May 1. Prof. William Williams, of the Baptist Theological Seminary, at Greenville, S. C., is dead. He was a man of large attainments.

Gen. M. La Rue Harrison, Special Agent of The Money Order System for the Post Office Department, yesterday, arrested George A. Buckingham, Postmaster at Riverhead, Long Island, on a charge of embezzling 81,659 84 money order funds. Buckingham was required to give bail for his appearance before the United States Grand Jury in Brooklyn at the next term of the District Court.

A meeting of the Board of Trustees of St. John's Guild was held last evening at the headquarters of the Guild, in Union-square, for the purpose of taking farther action toward securing an investigation of the charges made against the management of the institution and its Master, Rev. Alvah Wiswall.

A week ago today there were innumerable people in this city who predicted with a great deal of emphasis that if Rutherford B. Hayes was declared elected President of the United States he never would be allowed to take his seat peaceably.

Dwellings now being completed in the up-town district, along the line of improvement, promise to realize handsome returns to those who brought land and commenced operations last Summer, during the period of extreme depression.

At the Edinburgh Sheriff Criminal Court recently, two women, named Flora Margaret McConnochic and Donella McConnochie, were charged with forming a fraudulent scheme to obtain board and lodgings, as well as sums of money from persons residing in Edinburgh.

Patrolman Tyler, of the Broadway Squad, brought to Bellevue Hospital last evening an unknown lady whom he found on Broadway slightly in same. She appeared to be about 45 years of age, and was well dressed in black and were eye-glasses. The officer stated that the lady accosted him while he was at his post. and asked him to take her to a drug store.

Mr. J . A. Rocbuck recently furnished the Sheftfield Telegraph a copy of a letter written by John Stuart Mill to Sir Samuel Bentham, dated July 30, 1819. Mr. Reebuck, in his letter of transmittal, says: "The original I intend to send to the British Museum, as I consider it a piece of remarkable evidence respecting the education of a very remarkable man.

The European powers which were parties to the Treaty of Paris will furnish Russia with an opportunity for withdrawing without perceptible loss of dignity from her present attitude of hostility to Turkey, and of this opportunity Russia will be likely to avail herself; but the Ottoman Empire, from which the danger of hostile attack seems passing away, is making rapid strides toward administrative anarchy and the last throes of political dissolution.

It was not expected that the expiring Congress would do anything toward facilitating the resumption of specie payments, and nobody will be disappointed at the postponement of the consideration of Senator SHERMAN'S bill till December next.

The Senate, after a long discussion, by a vote of years 29, nays 11, receded from its amendments to the Post Office Appropriation bill, appropriating $500,000 for mail service, between San Francisco, China, and Japan, and a similar amount for service between New-Orleans and Rio Janeiro.

Ex-Gov. Horatio Seymour was in Chicago on Thursday and was interviewed by the Tribune. "I have no opinion on the political situation at this time." he said, "to the public. I have hardly kept posted within the past three days. It is naturally supposed that having spent so much of my time in public life I am interested in the politics of the country.

The Lexington (Ky.) Gazatle, a Democratic paper, thus expresses itself: "There are signs of returning reason on the subject of the whipping post. The spasm of humanitarianism is passing away and the ';ash for the thief's back,' so ardently recommended by the wise utterer of proverbs, is again coming into vogue.

President GRANT would have quitted Office with a better grace and more dignity had he abstained from lending himself to the lowest work of partisan politics in this State, and from promulgating certain loose and ill-considered declarations of Southern policy on the eve of making way for his successor.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: And now, in view of some suggestions to follow, it becomes necessary to determine who pay the $30,000,000 of annual taxes in this City. It is the owners of personal property. The generally received opinion is that it is the owners of real estate who pay the bulk of the City's annual tax.

Webster, C. L. Gerham,

Regina Armhold, the aged German woman who was found by the Police in a starving condition in her room at No. 90 Ridge-Street, on Friday night, and taken to Bellevue Hospital, died at the hospital seen after admission. The deceased was 60 years of age and was a native of schluchten, Wurtemberg.

The Portland (Oregon) Standard says: "A marriage certificate was issued by the County Clerk on Thursday, Feb. 7, to T. E. L. Logan, aged 22 years, and Minnie Dyer, aged 31 years. Logan is a florid-complexioned man, who was employed by the Chief of Police during the Prevalence of small-pox in the city to attend to the afflicted at the pest-house.

Col. C. H. Grosvenor, Speaker of the House of Representatives of the Ohio Legislature. makes the following statement in regard to the resolution said to have been passed on Friday by the Democrats of that body, in which they denounce the election of Mr. Hayes, and express a want of confidence in the Almighty:

Although the citizens of Staten Island are unanimous in the desire to have the inquest into the manner of the death of Katv Reidel reopened, and Coroner Dempsey, and the legal officers of Richmond County, sympathize with them, it is not likely that the inquiry will be resumed for some time, if ever.

The Rockport (Ind.) Republican says: "A story of the trials and disappointments of true love comes to us from Kentucky, wherein a young couple met with a sad railway disaster that, although it did them no bodily harm, crushed their hopes for the time. The lover in the case is young widower, from Richland, in this country, and the beloved a young lady, residing near Caseyville, Ky., whose parents were opposed to the match.

The Burlington (Iowa) Hawk-eye prints the following: " A sight that attracted many spectators appeared on our streets the other day. It was a team of oxen attached to a wood wagon. They were equipped in lull harness even to the bits, The collard and bames, instead of being placed as when on the equine beast, they rather were placed right the reverse-upside down.

The Kischeneff correspondent of the London News writes Feb. 9 as follows: "Few people probably have any idea of the size and importance of the place called Kischeneff. It is a place with a population of 100,000, and covering many square miles. Like nearly all Russian towns, the streets are very often 100 feet wide.
The schooner Margaret and Luey went to pieces near Life-saving Station No. 3, on the north side of Barnegat Inlet. All on board perished. She left ?? on Thursday last for Charleston, with a cargo.

Thirteen hundred and seventy arrests were made by the Police last week. The interest on City deposits for the month of February amounted to $1,429 29. Senator Morrissey and other members of the Legislature called on Mayor Ely yesterday. The schooner Alice Bell, of Wareham, sunk at the month of New-London harbor yesterday.

Yesterday the detectives engaged in assisting Capt. Worth, of the Sixth Precinct. Williamsburg, in ferreting out all the facts connected with the mysterious wounding of Annie Parker, of Wechers street, made their report. On the morning of Feb. 14 Miss Parker, whose identity at that time was unknown, was borne into Ollmer's drug store, on Graham-avenue, near Froat street.
At the semi-Centennial Convention last night of the Sigma Phi Society among those present was Charles T. Cromwell of New-York, the only surviving founder of the fraternity.

The trial of Joseph Coburn, for shooting at Officer William E. Tobias, of the Twenty-ninth Precinct, was resumed before Judge Sutherland yesterday, in Part II of the Court of General Sessions. His Honor fixed the hour of opening court at 10 o'clock, in order to expedite the progress of the trial, and the prisoner was brought to the courtroom before that hour by two court attendants.

A chronological outline of the political career of President Grant, from the day of his nomination at Chicago in 1868 to the time of his last prominent act--his eighth annual Message--will be found below. It will be useful in recalling many of the most important and exciting topics which have interested citizens of the United States for the past eight years.

Of all borrowers they who pay the most usurious interest are the borrowers of trouble; and the worst of it is that they are obliged to repay the debt in kind again and again without satisfying the claim.

The Forty-fourth Congress remains in session as we go to press, and is likely to do so to the last hour of its legal existence. There is the usual rush of bills, frequent reports from Conference Committees, and imminent danger of notorious jobs slipping through without the chance of effective opposition.

The Vienna correspondent of the Standard announces that the Czar has issued an ukase ordering the formation of four new artillery parks in Poland. The order has been renewed forbidding landowners in Poland from receiving more than five guests at the same time.

The Democratic presidential campaign, from its hopeful inception to its hopeless end, has been an unbroken series of mistakes. Politically speaking, a great party has seldom in our history found itself so advantageously posted to effect the dislodgment of its adversaries intrenched in power.

The usual statement of the week's statistics of the coal is thus furnished by the Pottsville (Penn.) Miners' Journal: "The quantity of coal sent from the Schuvlkill region for the week ending Feb. 24 was 52,735 tons; against 5.692 tons for the same week of last year--increase 47,043 tons.

Some excitement has been caused in Bombay by the arrest of a gang of clever forgers. A native broker was asked to dispose of a 1,000 rupee note, but the commission offered was so high that he took the note and made a simultaneous appointment with the Police and the forgers who were to bring four other notes.

THE WAGNER FESTIVAL. The promised series of representations of Wagner's operas at the Academy of Music is to commence on Monday evening week, when "Duer Fliegende Hollander', will to performed. "Tannbauser" will probably be brought out next; then "Lohengrin" is to be given, and, to worthily close the "Festival," it is intended to make known "Die Walkure."

The Copenhagen correspondent writing on Feb. 13 says: "The King of Sweden, who during the last week has been staying at Christiania to attend the opening of the Norwegian Chambers, paid a visit on Friday last to the Christiania Skating Rink.

The twenty-first annual festival in connection with the Dramatic, Equestrian, and Musical Sick Association took place last night at Willis' Rooms. Mr. J. W. Anson, the founder of the institution, occupied the chair.

Although rather early to allude to the subject of demi-saison suits, the unusually mild weather which has prevailed for the past month warrants some remarks upon the subject. Some beautiful toilets have just appeared in Paris.

THE CHRISTIAN DOCTRINE OF SIN. By JOHN TULLOCH, D. D., Principal of St. Mary's College in the University of St. Andrew's one of her Majesty's Chaplains for Scotland. New-York: SCRIBNER, ARMSTRONG Co. This instructive and interesting little volume of 250 pages has peculiar value from its treatment of an old subject by a new man in the new spirit of enlightened religion.

While the Police are actively searching for the murderer of the little girl thrown into the well at Bagneux, and who has not yet been found, the courts are preparing to try Billoir, the assassin of Marie Le Manach, and Godefroy, the person who figured in the drama of Auteuil.

Nothing whatever in theo record of the Forty-fourth Congress will hereafter challenge the admiration or respect of mankind. For various reasons, the popular branch, the House of Representatives, largely controls the legislation of Congress. The Democratic Party has had the misfortune to assume this responsibility,

An unlucky remark by the Augusta (Ga.) Chronicle has drawn out a long and pungent letter from Mr. Hugh A. Haralson, a leading Democrat of the State, in which he speaks his mind very frelly about the new Democratic State Administration, and Gov. Colquitt, its head.

The President's salary at one time threatened to defeat the passage of so important an appropriation bill as that which provides for the legislative, executive, and judicial expenses of the Government. The clause making the usual appropriation for the President's salary was in consonance with a similar enactment, passed four or five years ago, in which the amount was put at $50,000 per annum.

Gov. Packard made the following statement to-day to an Associated Press reporter: "I cannot say I anticipate any immediate attack upon the State-house, though in the excited condition of the public mind, fomented by constant sensational dispatches to the local press, such a thing is possible.

The convention of Irish civic societics in Brooklyn met at No. 26 Court-street yesterday afternoon to arrage for the celebration of St. Patrick's Day, Francis H. McGinniss, of the Ancient Order of Hibernians, in the chair. The ancient Order of Hibernians wanted James Ryan to be Marshal of the procession, and St. Patrick's Mutual Alliance urged the claims of ex-Alderman Henry Corr, of the Sixth Ward.

There are various opinions in regard to the necessity for an extra session of Congress, caused by the failure of the Army Appropriation bill. Of course it is out of the question that the military establishment of the United States shall be paralyzed by want of the usual appropriation for its maintenance.

On Monday evening Dr. Ginsburg, one of the members of the committee engaged in the revision of the Scriptures, delivered a lecture at the Town Hall. Wokingham, on "The Bible-The Mauner in which it has been Preserved, Transmitted, and Copies Multiplied."

At a meeting of the Seawanhaka Yacht Club. held at Delmonico's on Saturday evening, Commodore Center made an address on cruising yachts. He said there was broad distinction in England between cruising and racing yachts. The latter were very narrow and of great depth, carrying an enormous spread of canvas, and were good for racing only. The cruising yacht was designed for comfort.

Col. Meacham will deliver a lecture at Cooper Institute this evening on "The Tragedy in the Lava Beds." A stated meeting of the Board of Education will be held at the hall, Grand and Eim streets, on Wednesday next at 4 P. M. Hon. Frank Fuller delivered a lecture before the American Temperature Union, at the Cooper Institute, yesterday, on "Alcohol as a Food Substance."

A new life-saving rocket is shortly to be exhibited at Sandy Hook by Capt. F. F. Atkinson, formerly of the Fourth King's Royals, British Army. The invention has entirely superseded the old-fashioned stick rocket along the British coast, and during its trial last December by the Sussex Coast Guard of England, Mr. Hooper, the inventor, sent six rockets carrying ordinary coast lines a distance of 350 yards over a vessel 60 feet in length.

A curious and as yet, impenetrable mystery, involving the death of some unknown man, is engaging the attention of the residents in the western section of the city, and more especially those in the vicinity of the Centennial Grounds. The remains of a stranger, much decomposed, being doubtless, all that is left of some Centennial visitor,

Parliament opened without a fight on the address. The Opposition waited until the Tory chiefs had spoken, and then took counsel together. Even then they arranged no positive programme. They, nevertheless; commenced the preliminaries which usually lead up to pitched battles. Independent members asked question; Liberal Leaders asked questions.

"Wild Oats" will be acted this evening at Wallack's Theatre. Capt. Wraa's life-saving apparatus will be exhibited at Gilmore's Garden to-night. The sale of season Seats for the Wagner Festival begins at the Academy of Music this morning.

The Richmond (Va.) Dispatch of the 3d inst., says; "The difficulty in the way Dr. Moffett's system of taxing consumers of whisky is so to adjust it as not to impose it altogether upon the retailer of whisky; or on the other hand, to give the retailer the opportunity of not only imposing the State tax on the consumer.

At noon yesterday, while Sergt. Reilley, of the Eighth Precinet, was standing at the corner of Grand and Sullivan streets, he noticed John Collius, of No. 68 Thompson-street, who was intoxicated, insult two ladies who were passing. The Sergeant told Collins to desist and go home, but Collins refused to leave, and defied the Sergeant to arrest him.

Justice Davis will appear with his associates of the Supreme Court at the inauguration ceremonies to-morrow, and will subsequently resign to President Hayes his office as Associate Justice. There was quiet within the Executive Mansion during the day. The ex-President and Mrs. Grant, Col. Grant and Mrs. U. S. Grant, remain there, and will leave tomorrow morning.

The lady who was found on Saturday wandering in Broadway in a state of dementia, and who was taken to Bollevue Hospital, proves to be Mrs. Teresa Goodman, of Elizabeth City, N. J., where she resides with Mr.s J. B. Wheeler, at nO. 369 Morris-avenue. She is a very respectable lady. 58 years of age, and is subject to sudden attacks of aberration of the mind. She had fully recovered her senses yesterday,

There are in this snow nearly 2,000 entries, the actual number being about 600 over any previous total. As a whole, the quality of the vast display is almost as remarkable as its quantity: and, except for the sweeping disqualification of foreign bulifinches, boldly entered as British birds, no class has suffered detraction from the general praise awarded it by the judges.

All of the great appropriation bills, with one exception, had passed when the Fortyfourth Congress dissolved by constitutional limitation at noon yesterday. This excoption was the Army Appropriation bill, which failed to become a law merely because the Democratic majority in the House insisted upon attaching to it a clause from the platform of the St. Louis Convention of 1876.

TILDEN'S castle in the air has melted quite away. It was a good structure while it lasted. All that lying and braggadocio could do for it was done. But after all, it was a castle in the air. Most well-regulated minds regarded the compaign of 1876 as a doubtful one.

While we are in Kentucky and among Kentuckians I cannot get my own consent to pass in silence the name of another of its prominent cittzene, although perhaps not among the famous, still among the most notorious of his time.

ALLERTON.--Saturday, March 3. DAVID ALLERTON, in the 59th year of his age. Funeral Tuesday, March 6, at 1 o'clock from his late residence, East Chester. Train leaves Grand Central Depot for Mount Vernon, New-Havan Railroad, at 12 M. BROWN.--In Brooklyn, on the 3d inst., Mrs. CATHERINE BROWN, in the 82d year of her age.

Neil Campbell formerly a Police officer of Jorsey City, was arrested on Saturday night for cruelty to animals. Patrick Haight and his dog were passing Campbell's place when the dog assaulted a cat sitting in the doorway. Campbell seized a butcher-knife and plunged it into the dog's back. The dog ran squealing down the street with the knife in his back. pursued by Haight.
The St. Louis Times prints a brief correspondence which lately passed between a new Illinois Democrats and Congressmen in W. R. Morrison. On the 24th ult. the former telegraphed to Mr. Morrison:

The area of lowest pressure has moved north-westward beyond our stations, and rising or high barointer now prevails over nearly the entire country east of the Rocky Mountains, being highest in Missouri, Cooler north-west winds with clear weather prevail in the Middle and Eastern States, westerly winds and partly cloudy weather in the Ohio and Missouri Valleys, northerly winds, cloudy weather and occasional light rain in the south-west.

The closing hours of the Senate were marked by good judgement and decorum. The body remained in session until 3 o'clock A. M., when a recess was taken to 9 o'clock. At that hour all the Senators were in their seats.

Speaker RANDALL received the usual compliment of a eulogistic resolution from the House just before adjournment. It is customary for such a resolution to be offered by one of the opposition members, in order that it may express tile sentiment of the House rather than the partisan opinion of the majority.

When a grocer's boy yesterday delivered a basket full of packages to a lady on Columbia-street her quick eve detected the tact that she he had recoived only 11 oranges in place of a dozen. "Young man, you ate that other orange as you came along I" she exclaimed, as she recounted the number.

The extensive tobacco factory of Leggatt, Hudson Butler, Nos. 1,903 and 1,905 Buel-street, was totally destroyed by fire this morning. The loss is estimated at $60,000; insurance $2,500 in each of the following companies: Howard and picenix, of New-York; North American, Manhattan, Pennsylvania Fire,

An attempt was made in the debate now proceeding in the British Parliament to commit the Tory Party to a pledge that they will maintain the treaty of Paris in the support of Turkey. Lord Stratheden's motion to this effect in the House of Lords night before last was opposed, however, by one of the Tory leaders themselves, Earl Derby.

For the relief of those anxious persons who have thought that the safety of the Republic would be endangered if the Presidential term should expire on Sunday, it may be said that President HAYES took the oath of office on Saturday night.

William Adams, a colored waiter, employed by Mrs. Murphy, of No. 35 East Ninth-street, was arraigned at the Washington-place Police Court yesterday morning, charged with stealing a pocket-book containing $307, and some valuable papers, the property of Mrs. E. J. Creighton, a lady who boarded in the house. It appears that Adams was only temporarily employed,

Some time between 10 o'clock on Saturday night and 9 o'clock yesterday morning the jewelry store of Casper N. Gunther. No. 779 Falton-street, was entered by burglars through side doors on Oxford-street opening into a room at the rear of the store, in the front part of which, facing the window of the store on Fulton-street, which had the certain down, was a sale containing watches, lockets, and other jewelry, of the value of $4,345.

The British fleet sailed from the Piracus this morning for Malta. BERLIN, March 4.--Gen. Ignatieff has arrived in this city. LONDON, March 4.--Reuter's dispatch from Paris says Gen. Ignatieff goes to London and Paris. The Powers will delay their replies to Gortsohakoff's circular until Ignatieff's mission is ended.

There is no doubt that Mr. HAYES will be given a fair trial in good faith by the great majority of the people of the country. His own political supporters--who are in majority of nearly a million in the Northern States--will, of course, await his course as President with patient ce and candor, and there is every reason to expect that the great body of intelligent Democrats will do the same.

The Patapsco Guano Company's Works, on Philpot, near Dock street, were burned this afternoon. The Chesapeake main railroad, adjoining, was badly damaged. The loss to the Guano Company is estimated at from $75,000 to $100,000, and is covered by insurance, distributed as follows: Hartford, of Connecticut; Home, of New-York, and National of Baltimore, $7,000 each; Baltimore, Peabody, Howard Associated,...

Lieut. E. L. Amory, United States Navy, is at the Brevoort House. Prof. D. C. Gilman, President of the Johns Hopkins University, is at the St. James Hotel. Assistant Postmaster General E. W. Barber and A. D. Hazen, of the Post Office Department, are at the Gilsey House.

The Greensboro (N. C.) New North State gives the following account of a remarkably sudden death. recently briefly alluded to in our telegrams : " A very sad occurrence took place at Thomasville on Thursday, Feb. 22.

The ninth annual report of the Inebriates' Home for Kings County, which has just been published, furnished the following information: During the last year 279 cases have been treated in the institution, including 35 readmissions. Of this number 230 entered voluntarily, and 49 were committed by the courts. The average time the patients submitted to treatment was 35 weeks and 4 days. There were only two trains dispatched to Washington by the Pennsylvania Railroad yesterday. These left at the regular hours, at 6 o'clock, and 9 o'clock P. M. The 6 o'clock train comprised six cars, all well filled, but the 9 o'clock train was composed of two sections drawn by separate engines, the first section comprising eight cars and the second seven.

One day when the venerable Turgot was Intendant General of Finance, a "very seedy-looking" person, with a hat in a pitiable condition, was introduced into the audience chamber of the Minister. The man had a wonderful project "by which he could give the King 150,000,000 francs."

A writer in Macmillan's Magazine, a portion of whose article will be found in our edition of last Sunday, makes an extraordipary admission in regard to British naval architecture. It is to the effect that what little improvement there was in British war ships after twenty years naval warfare with France was due mainly to copying the better designs of the French ships which were captured during the war.

Forty years ago, the venerable Dr. Charles Lowell being then the Pastor of this church, Mr. Bartol was settled as his associate and assistant.

The Vienna Correspondent of the Times states that the progress made toward carrying out the proposal to give a respite to Turkey consists in Russia's having dropped the Idea of getting the powers to agree to coercive measures.

The brief speech which Mr. HAYES made yesterday at the Capital is likely to meet with approval throughout the country. It was dispassionate, though sincere and earnest in tone, and without a trace of anything like partisanship. Its topics were selected with judgment, and the attention given to them was proportioned with excellent discretion.

There can be nothing magical in the effect of the peaceful inauguration of Mr. HAYES, but the event will in all probability be found to be the beginning of the end of that period of depression and distrust which the uncertainties of the Presidential contest have unduly lengthened.

Judge Lawrence, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, reserved his decision on the question of granting an extra allowance to the City in the suit of Owen W. Andrews as Referee in the suit of Josephine McNeill against James McNeill.

Although the Presidential election was a year off when the first session of the Forty- ti fourth Congress began, that Congress was as much a President-making one as any of its predecessors. For the first time in many years, the Democrats had secured control of the House of Representatives.

At a meeting of the Psychological Society, at their rooms in Chandos-street, Cavendish-square, on Thursday night, a paper road by Mr. Coffin on electro-biology gave rise to a discussion, in the course of which Mr. Serjeant Cox, the President, said he had tried mesmeric experiments very often at one period of his life, and he was quite satisfied of their genuineness.

The brigantine Albion which arrived at this port yesterday from Cionfuegos, reports that on Feb. 5. when 30 miles north of Gun Key, of the Bahaman Islands, a low rakish looking schooner, about 60 tons, passed her. Shortly after the Albion came up with a Spanish brig from Cienfuegos, for Spain.

The alleged election frauds in San Francisco, about which such an outcry was made at the time by the Democrats, have just been investigated by the local authorities. The report of the committee shows that about three thousand votes were cast by unauthorized persons.

Marysville, Cal., possesses a unique mule. There is a wearisome sameness in the vast majority of mules. The same fondness for pausing at inopportune moments for profound meditation, the same habit of reaching after the infinite with both hind legs, and the same tendency to stand on the head whenever the road is particularly muddy or stony, characterize at least ninetynine out of every ono hundred mules.

Chicago, to enjoin the production of Mr. McVicker's adaptation of the play "Lemons," claimed by Mr. Daly as his exclusive property.

Mayor Ely has signed the municipal resolutions providing for renumbering a portion of Broadway. These conferences are provided for by the resolution of Alderman Parroy, which was adopted by the Common Council some time since.

The contest for the succession to the Presidency, which has just been concluded by the declaration of the election of Rutherford B. Hayes, will pass into history as the most remarkable which has occurred in the life of the nation. It began in the month of June, 1876; it ended only on the morning of the 2d of March, 1877.

The London School Board have printed information regarding the salaries of teachers in the schools under the board. The highest salary paid to any one teacher is [Pound] 975, and this is supplemented by the Government grant in a very large school, amounting to $478, with $150 for the instruction of pupil teachers, and $24 for drawing grant, making in the whole $1.627.

At the meeting of the Board of Police yesterday the complaint against Capt. Henry Hedden, of the Thirty-third Precinct, was brought up for consideration. The Captain was charged with having borrowed money from certain members of his command, in violation of the rules of the department. He virtually admitted the charges.

Collector Long, of St. Louis, is reported to have received a letter from President Grant, in which he indicates more definitely than has yet been stated what his intentions are upon leaving office. He requests Mr. Long to continue the charge he now has of Gen. Grant's farm and other property in St. Louis, exercising a supervision until the Generel's return from Europe.

The New-York Microscopical Society held a reception last evening in Kurtz's Art Gallery ,in Twenty-third-street. The floor was checkered with small square tables on which stood numerous miscroscopes of the latest improved character. These were lighted by argand lamps, and in the centres were tall square transparencies with moveable paper sides, into which the attendant members put inscribed slides bearing the names of the various objects exhibited.

A debate which slightly warmed up the House this morning took place on Mr. Cowdin's bill relating to street cleaning in New-York. This bill provides that the streets shall be cleaned by contract, the contracts to be for small districts, and all power and authority over the work is retained in the Police Board.

The distinguished surgeon, Dr. Gurdon Buck, died at his residence, No. 46 West Twenty-ninth-street, yesterday morning. Dr. Buck was born in this City on May 4, 1807, and was consequently in his 70th year. He was the son of Mr. Gurdon Buck, a preminent New-York merchant in his day, who married Miss Susannah Manwaring.

Tilden would arrive this evening, on an Eastern train, was industriously circulated here to-day by influenced Democrats anxious to offer that gentleman an ovation. WASHINGTON, March 7.--It is understood that the reorganized Senate committees will be announced to-morrow. Mr. Morton will remain Chairman of Privileges and Elections, and Simon Cameron will continue at the head of the Committee on Foreign Relations.

Ex-President Grant was among the visitors on the floor. He entered the Chamber before the discussion began, leaning upon the arm of Senator Conkling, and occupied the seat of that Senator for nearly one hour.

A regular meeting of the Board of Education was held yesterday, President Wood in the chair. The School Superintendent reported that during January 21 day and 31 evening schools had been examined. In the day schools 252 classes were examined, and the instruction in 156 found to be excellent, while in the evening schools 259 classes were examined, and 145 reported as excellent.
The case in which the will of ex-Judge Michael Connolly is contested by his daughter, Ellen Louisa Healy, was resumed yesterday before Surrogate Calvin.

WASHINGTON, March 7.--Well-informed friends of the President assert that the nomination of Senator Key to the Cabinet is the initial step in the development of the policy seeking to disarm Southern distrust and promote peace in that section on the basis of justice and protection to all.

ALBANY, March 7.--The Senate Chamber was the scene of an unusua1ly heated debate this morning on the subject of the Reapportionment bill. Senator Jucobs offered a resolution instructing the comnittee having the matter in charge to report a bill within 10 days.

William Maxwell Evarts was born in Boston, Mass., Feb. 6, 1818. His father was Jeremiah Evarts, who was graduated at Yale College in 1802 and who, after four years' practice at the Bar in New-Haven, became the editor of a religious magazine, was in 1812 chosen Treasurer of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions, and afterward wrote a number of essays on the rights of the Indians.

ALBANY, Wednesday, March 7, 1877. The sporting men, who have been boast ing recently in the lobbies of the Fifth Avenue and the Hoffman House that they had laid away the bill to prohibit pool-selling with a weight of $5,000 upon it, will now step up and explain how it was that the bill would not remain where it was laid.

From early morning until dark yestertay the smoking ruins of the Bond-street fire were the centre of attraction for large numbers of sightseers and curiosity seekers, who, behind files of policemen, stood for hours watching the operations of the begrimed and fatigued firemen employed in tearing down the toppling walls, and in endeavoring to extinguish the flames which still burned fiercely in the basement of the building.

At the Fifty-seventh-street Police Court yesterday, a woman, who gave her name as Abigail Parker, of Wilmington, Del., was arraigned on a charge of disorderly conduct, preferred by James O. Hoyt, of No. 16 East Fifty-eighth-street From what could be learned it appears that Miss Parker has been a resident of this country for many years.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 7.--State Senator E. L. Weber has just received information from the Parish of West Feliciana, by telegram from Bayou Sara, that his brother, D. A. Weber, was killed this afternoon at 3 o'clock. No detailed statement of the murder has arrived, nothing but the bare fact that four or five shots were fired from the Court-house yard.

Lafayette Grover, of Oregon, presented himself in the Senate to be sworn in as Senator from that State, but objection was made and he was not sworn. Later, Mr. Mitchell, of Oregon, presented petitions from that State asking that Grover be not seated, as his election was secured by bribery and fraud, and also because of his couduct in the Electoral vote case.
An the Emma Mine case yesterday the crossexamination of Trenor W. Park was continued by Mr. Stonghton, but nothing of importance was elicited.

While the Senate of the United States is deliberating upon the appointments made for Cabinet officers by President Hayes, many leading citizens of this and other cities, without regard to party connections, are already speaking boldly their approval of the President's selections.

Both houses of the Legislature have addressed themselves steadily to their work that the session may be brought to its final close to-morrow. During the last few days a large amount of business has been transacted and many bills have been passed.

There was a rather ludicrous termination of the Coburn case yesterday. It seems that Charles W. Brooke, the prisoner's counsel, and Assistant District Attorney Rollins appeared before Judge Lawrence, in Supreme Court, Chambers at 10:30 A. M. yesterday, to argue about getting a stay in the case.

Capt. Roberts, of the ship Fannie Tucker, which arrived to-day from Calcutta, reports that on the 22d of October, in latitude 6 north, longitude 85 east, he fell in with the English ship Kate Gregory, from Calcutta to Point De Galle, which was on fire.

Letters received per steamer Newbern, at this port, from Mazatlan, report that Mijoni, Mexican Collector of Customs at Mazatian, forcibly detains the American schooner Montana under arbitrary ruling and false interpretations of international law. The Montana cleared Jan.

The Atlas Company's steamer Etna arrived from Savanna and Carthagena at Aspinwall on the night of the 23d, and will leave for N. W. York to-day. The steamer Colon arrived at Aspinwall on the evening of the 23d, from New-York. The Panama Government has obtained the "loan" of $30,000 "asked" for.
The Joint Committee on Cities ot the Assembly and Senate held a meeting late to-night, and resolved on making most important changes in the City Government.

St. Francis Xavier's Church, in Sixteenth-street, was last night filled with a congregation exclusively of women. A mission of Jesuits was in progress, when, in the midst of the sermon by one of the fathers, at about 8:30 o'clock, the shriek of an hysteric woman in one of the galleries, and a heedless cry on fire which followed it, created a panic.

ANDERSON--PECK.--On the 6th inst., by Rev. a. H. Partridge, of Christ Church, WILSON G. HUNT ANDERSON to ELIZABETH E. PECK, all of Brooklyn. HULL--HOLLEY.--At Poughkeepsie N. Y., on Wednesday, March 7, 1877, by Rev. J. R. Kendrick, D. D. J. FRANK BULL, Jr., to LUDA R. HOLLEY, daughter of the late George W. Sterling.

The cross-examination of Trenor W. Park, the principal defendant in the Emma Mine case, was continued yesterday, in the United States Circuit Court, before Judge Wallace, the witness being examined with great spirit and some warmth by Mr. Stoughton, while the opposing counsel, Messrs. Phelps and Chittenden.

The Baptist Social Union of Manhattan, Island held their regular monthly meeting last night at Delmonice's Fifth-avenue and Twenty-sixth-street. There were about 100 members present. After enjoying a rich collation, the question was discussed as to "the value of Young Men's Christain Associations as helper in Church work."
The Saratogian of the 7th inst. says "Enough towns have been heard from to show that old Saratoga County has returned again to her allegiance to the Republican Party.

A private collection of paintings belonging to Mr. Silas C. Evaus has been hung in the large south roam at the Academy of Design, on the Corner of Fourth-avenue and Twenty-third-street, where it may be seen without charge until sold. The auction will take place on the evenings of Wednesday and Thursday, March 14 and 15,

The Cabinet chosen by President Hayes gives general satisfaction here. The Tribune says; " President Hayes' candid selection cannot fail to give very general satisfaction In ability character, and moral fitness the appointment are really above criticism."

"Alice Le Cour," called Judge Smith, at the Fifty-seventh-street Court yesterday morning, and in response a young woman in deep mourning stepped out from among the crowd of frowat female prisoners. She was only 18, she said, but she had already passed through a course of dissipation which had undermined her health and left her a burden to herself and friends.

The London Economist, in a long and somewhat labored article, undertakes to explain the causes which have produced what it is pleased to call "a great fall in American railroad securities." That a fall of some extent has taken place in a few securities of this kind is true;

A serenade was tendered to George William Curtis and Oliver P. Flske last night by the citizens of New-Brighton, Statn Island,irrespective of party. The movement was spontaneous, and the enthusiastic manner in which it was participated in showed the esteem in which the above named Gentlemen are held.

Two young white men, named Washington McGraw and William Mahoney, while under the influence of liquor last evening, were assaulted by four negroes in the Capital grounds, who escaped arrest. Officers of the Capital Police force discovered the young men lying on the terrace above the fish-pond in front of the entrance to the Capital. McGraw was dead.

In the executive Session of the Senate to-day the nomination of Senator Sherman to be Secretary of the Treasury was confirmed after an hour's debate. The Senate did not adjourn till 5 o'clock. The other nominations were left to take their course under the rules.

The Seventeenth annual commencement exercises of the New-York Homeopathic Medical College were held last evening in Chickering Hall. The hall was crowded with the friends of the graduating class and of the members of the Junior Class, who expect to be licensed to practice in the middle of March, 1878.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I voted for Tilden, also for Seymour, also for Greeley. and in fact for every Demooratic candidate since 1840; and now, knowing that Mr. Hayes is a perfectly competent man for theo Presidency, a pertectly honest man, and a man of true courage, and a good citizen, I wish to make an early declaration of my intention to support him.

The case of Mr. Morgan, of Alabama, was disposed of after considerable discussion, by admitting him to a seat in the senate without division. The resolution to admit ex-Gov. Grover, of Oregon, to a seat was taken up, and an addition to it to refer the petitions and charges of citizens of Oregon against Grover to the Committee on Elections when organized.

Edward Kulikowski, editor of a weekly Polish journal published in Brooklyn, called the Kurier Nowojorski, committed suicide yesterday afternoon. He was found lying sick on the grass in Prospect Park by a policeman, and was assisted to his office, on Bond-streer, corner of Fulton.

Cattle--Receipts to-day, 306 head; total for the week thus far, 7,888 head; for the same time last week, 7,293 head; increase, 35 cars for the week; consigned through , 312 cars: fresh arrivals consigned through; sales of 6 cars for the Eastern trade at yesterday's quotations; 10 cars unsold.

The Butter and Egg Convention to-day received congratulations from the various exchanges in the country. 0. S. Bliss, Secretary of the Vermont Dairymen's Association, read an article on the dairy interests, showing that the ideal cow would make a net profit to the owner of $122 per year.

Ex-Gov. Pinchback, of Louisiana, has received a telegram from New-Orleans signed by a number of members of the Republican State Central Committee asserting that they condemn the action of the committee asking his resignation.

About 9:40 o'clock last night, 50 feet of the front of the immense brick grocery storehouse at the corner of Washington and Franklin streets, owned and occupied by Henry Walsh, wholesale grocer, fell out with a terrible crash, and covered that part of Washington-street immediately in front with a chaotic mass of brick, mortar, kegs, firkins, and loose provisions.

Henry Frederick Moeller assigned his property for the benefit of creditors to John Carlson yesterday. In reporting the anniversary exercises of the Seamen's Bethel Temperance Society yesterday the title of Seamen's Friend Society was inadvertently used.

The ruins in Bond-street Presented a busy scene yesterday. During the preceding night three streams of water were kept playing on the smonidering mass (of debris which filled the cellar and sub-cellar of the building, and when dawn appeared it was found that the ruins had become sufficiently cool to be conveniently handled.

It is not surprising to hear that Senator CAMERON agrees with Mr. BLAINE in condemning the Southern policy of the President. As that policy has merely been announced in general terms, and as its outlines thus given have received the emphatic approval of the vast majority of the party, it is not very easy to understand the grounds of disapproval discovered by these eminent statesmen.

The Union League Club undoubtedly includes a large number of the best Republicans in New-York, and shares with the party its hearty satisfaction with President HAYES' course, but the gentlemen who were charged with giving expression to this feeling last evening cannot be said to have arranged a very imposing demonstration.

The topic of the hour is the funeral of Mr. John O'Mahony. I dare say you have had your won share of worry in this matter, and that New-York has in all probability heard enough of a scheme which seems likely to breed mischief.

The new United States frigate Trenton, which left the Navv-yard on Monday last and anchored off the Battery, to take on board her stores of gunpowder, , from Ellis Island, tripped her anchors at noon yesterday and proceeded down the Bay to the Compass Buoys, off Sandy Hook. There she stayed to test her compasses.

It was the Tweed Ring, we believe, that invented the farce of the Municipal conference. As soon as the Legislature assembled, Senators and Assemblymen began to consider various projects for the improvement of our City Government.

The scandal caused by Adelina Patti is now the main subject of gossip in the saloons and in the clubs. The news fell like a thunderbolt upon the artistic world of Paris. The idea of La Patti running away with a common tenor, after being for so many years a titled and respected lady, held up as a model to all young ladies upon the stage, was almost beyond conception.

ANDERSON.--At Yonkers, March 7, HESTER, wife of Alfred Anderson. in her 77th year. Funeral this afternoon from the First Methodist Church, Youngers, at 2 o'clock. Relatives and friends of the family are invited.

In answer to the foregoing inquiry the Vicksburg (Miss.) Herald of the 4th inst. says: At no time since the war has the South occupied so important a position as now. At non time before have her destinies been within the control of her own people. In the last election she stood like a stone wall for reform and justice to hereself.

A fire in the Posey block on Main-street, Evansville, Ind., yesterday morning, destroyed Weber's hat store and Gross' clothing store. Weber's loss is $31,000; insurance $2,300. Gross' loss is $20,000 insurance $12,000. The loss on the building is $20,000; insurance $11,000.

The Assembly have settled down to the discussion of the series of amendments to New-York City legislation, generally known as the Woodin Charter bill. The bill was a very good one as originally presented, but was slightly emasculated before being introduced, and was amended in committee on the recommendation of the Corporation Counsel.

Judge Sterret is an honorable, ?? man, a fine jurist, and an able Judge. He will bring honor and dignity to the court. t.

In response to the short call made by a number of prominent bankers and merchants through THE TIMES yesterday morning, and attracted by a hastily gotten-up placard that was posted on the Treasury building, bearing the inscription, "Stand by the President! Meeting at 1 o'clock," a crowd of several thousand persons assembled on the corner ot Wall and Broad streets shortly atter the hour mentioned.

What the Wall-street meeting to sustain the President lacked in formal preparation, it gained in spontaneous enthusiasm. There could be no mistaking the temper of the business. men who crowded around the steps of the Sub-Treasury in regard to the stand which the President is making on the questions of reform and justice to the South.

A letter from Havana, dated the 3d inst., says that the steamer sent out by the owner of the burned steamer Moctezuma, as well as the gun-boat sent out by the Government, to raise, if possible, the hull of the Moctezuma, have returned, not having been able to fulfill their mission, as the hull had partially broken up and had sunk.

A joint caucus of Republican members of the General Assemblyin reference to the United States Senatorship was held this evening. but without result, definite action being deemed as yet premature.

To the Veteran Soldiers and Sailors of the United States : COMRADES : The late election of President and Vice-President, in which you here so conspicuous and efficient a part, has just been consummated by the induction of Rutherford B. Hayes and William A. Wheeler into these high and responsible offices.

This evening's representation at the Eagle Theatre is given for the benefit of M. Daplan, one of the most amusing comedians now upon the stage. The work to be performed is "Les Deagous de Villars," an oepra coinique, strongly dramatic in its story, and of positive lyric merit.

The feeling of the people generally toward the President does not admit of doubt. Here and there partisan animosity displays itself with as much maliguity as though tile election were still pending, but the exceptions are so rare that they only render more conspicuous the prevailing disposition to make allowance for his difficulties and judge of his policy by its results.

From the Richmond (Va.) Whig. We shall wait for acts before we pass judgment. The Concluding language of the inaugural we fancy: it sounds familiar to us: its use by his Excellency assures us of his famillarty with a good book. May be live up to its catholic teachings, and inspire by his acts the faith of his countrymen in his wisdom and patriotism.

In executive session yesterday, the Senate confirmed the nomination of Mr. SHERMAN as Secretary of the Treasury. The reason assigned for immediate action in his case was the necessity of determining whether Mr. SHERMAN should be regarded as still holding a place in the Senate, and as, consequently, retaining his position at the head of the Committee on Finance.

The fatal accident in the Church of St. Francis Xavier, West Sixteenth-street, last night, was both singular and deplorable. The edifice was crowded with women, and the atmosphere was oppressive. A woman fainted and fell with some appearance of hysterics.

The plan agreed upon by the Joint Committee of the Senate and Assembly for the reconstruction of our City departments seems to be carefully considered and eminently practical. Details are wanting in regard to some of its most important provisions, but the points which are given show that the need of radical changes in our administrative machinery has not been lost sight of.

Every sportsman concedes that fly-fishing is the only way in which fish should be captured by beings with immortal souls. The small boy, however, has a strong prejudico against the fly. This is partly due to the fact that in order to fish with a fly ho must borrow his father's fly-rod.

The Presidential question is at last settled, and new hats are now in order for all parties. Political differences should be promptly buried, and the people should smile, shake bands all round, and then go to work. But what can a gentleman do without a new hat?

We confess that we do not think the President or the country has very much to expect from the Committee on the Civil Service in the Senate in aid of a radical reform. The Committee stands as follows: Mr. BLAINE, Chairman; Messrs. OGLESBY, PATTERSON, BOOTH, McCREERY, WHYTE, and Beck.

The processes of planting, cultivating, and marketing cotton have already.-been explained. Before leaving this chief production of the farm it is well to give some estimate of the financial results of the present method of culture, and call attention to the probable results of general improvements to be derived from a more intelligent and thorough system.

The events of tho past few weeks at Washington have detracted somewhat from the interest usually taken by the people of this State in their annual election. As a natural consequence, the canvass has been more quietly conducted than for manny years. Nevertheless, New-Hampshire Republicans fully recognize the importance of next Tuesday's election, both to the State and to the nation, and Will keep the old Granite State at the head ot the column.

A very pecuhar feature of this morning's session was the continuous contests which took place over reports from committees. The issue ot these could not be revived with unmixed satisfaction. As usual, the subjects of dispute were the rights, privileges, and powers of cor- porations, and in each case they were NewYork corporations.

Joe Coburn passed here to-night in a drawing-room car and heavily ironed. These were only two seats in the compartment, the other being occupied by Special Detective James Jackson. of Sing Sing Prison. Neither knew at the trip they were to take until 5:30 o'clock this afternoon, when a special draft was made for Coburn to go to Auburn Prison.

A convention of window glass manufacturers of the United States closed a three days' session at the Monongahela House last night. Over 40 firms from all parts of the country were represented, while many others sent retards and signified their concurrence in the object of the meeting.

It has been ascertained that Blacklock, who was arrested in New-York on charge of embezzlement, is the voungest of the Hurle brothers, who figured extensively in Chicago, St. Louis, Louisville, Cincinnati, and other places 10 years ago as confidence men.

Judge Isaac Ames, of the Probate Court, died in Boston yesterday. He was 57 years old. Hon. Oliver Ames, brother of the late Oakes Ames, died at his residence at Easton, Mass., yesterday morning. His connection with the celebrated manufactory, and his more recent co-operation in building the Union Pacific Railroad, have made his name widely known.

The second trial of Alexander Sullwan for the murder of Francis D. Hanford in this city last August, which has been before the Criminal Court the past 11 days, has come to a conclusion. The case was given to the jury about 5 o'clock, and at mid-night a verdict of acquittal was returned, and this on the third ballot, but one member of the jury holding out.

Grammar School No, 37 in Eighty -- Seventh -- Street, near Third-avenue, was dedicated last evening by a grand exhibition of musical and literary exercises., The school, Which is one of the most commodious in the City, was thronged to its utmost capacity by the parents and friends of the pupils. On the rostrum were seated Hon.

The Honolulu Gazette of Feb. 28 contains an account of a remarkable submarine volcanic outbreak in kealkeakaua Bay, near the entrance to the harbor. The natives report that the eruption occurred at 3 o'clock on the morning of the 24th, appearing like innumerable red, blue, and green lights.

Express Train No. 4, bound east over the Air Line Division of the Lake Shore and Michigan Southern Railway, came in collision with a west-bound freight train near Corunna, Ind., this afternoon. Both engines were badly wrecked and the fireman of the freight engine slightly hurt. No one else was injured. The mail and baggage cars were destroyed by fire, with a portion of their contents.

The trial of James Edward Pantiell, for the murder of his wife, which has been in progress since Feb. 20, in the Court of Quarter Sessions, was concluded this morning. The murder was committed on the 21st of July, 1876. On that day he called at his wife's mother's and remained over night, the next morning going to the hotel to see his wife.

The Dock Commissioners yesterday hold a Special meeting for the purpose of considering the recent application of the White Star Steam-ship Company for permission to lay tracks along Pier No. 45 North River, to connect with the Belt Line and the Now-York Central, for the delivery of freight from their steamers.

The Park Commissioners will meet to-day at their office, to consider the question of building the proposed bridge over the Harlem River, from Madison-avenue to One Hundred and Thirty-eighth-street. The Mayor and Controller are to be present for the purpose of obtaining information as to the cost of the work and of the land approached to the structure.

Hon. John M. Francis, of Troy, is at the St. James Hotel. Judge James H. Howe, of Wisconsin, is at the Windsor Hotel. Bishop John Sharp, of Salt Lake City, is at the St. Nicholas Hotel. Ex-Congressman John O. Whitehouse, of Poughkeepsie, is at the Albemarie Hotel.

The Bangor (Me.) Whig says: "When Leg surrendered his army to Grant the latter declined to take his sword, and added to the magnanimity by voluntarily inserting in the terms of capitulation an exemption of 'the side-arms of (all) the officers and their horses and private baggage.'

At a meeting of the Gold Exchange, held about two weeks ago, resolutions were offered dissloving the exchange, but the Chairman ruled them out of order, on the ground that there was nothing in the consistution to provide for its dissolution and the distribution of the assets. In order to get over this difficulty, the following amendment to the constitution, signed by E. M. Merrill, A. A.

During the stormy sequel to the anomalous struggle before the Commission, there were some piquant surprises in the House of Representatives. The course of certain Southern Democrats brought sore disappointment to their Northern compeers, who had counted on their indisputable bravery in case of a perilous extremity, but who soon began to rail against them, "giving aid.

The Turkish Minister of Foreign Affairs has sent the following dispatch to the Ottoman Ambassador at London: The reforms proposed by the conference and accepted by the Imperial Government are already being applied.

The Fourteenth Assembly District Boys in Blue Republican Association met last evening at No. 96 Third-avenue, John H. Brady presiding. The meeting was very enthusiastic over the inauguration of President Hayes and Vice-President Wheeler. A brass band discoursed several patriotic airs.

Augustus G. Stinson, a well-known citizen and merchant of Boston, Mass., committed suicide yesterday morning by jumping off one of the Fulton Ferry boats. The deceased, who was 60 years of age, had accumulated a large fortune in business, but recently he experienced heavy financial losses, which appeared to unsettle his mind.

It is fully 16 years since the Army Regulations were revised. The only volume of regulations in existence was published as far back as 1861, though in 1863 an appendix containing certain information affecting the Army and the articles of war was added. Since then the Army Regulations has been left untouched, and of late especially, it has been impossible to secure all extra copy of the book in question.

It now appears probable and nearly certain that all the Cabinet appointments will be confirmed. The delay which has occurred in an act which ought to have been prompt and cordial, has had one good offect. It has shown that the Senate, as at present constituted, is open to the influence of public opinion.

The Nereid Boat-Club, of Brooklyn, held their regular annual meeting Thursday evening, when Joseph P. Earle, Captain; Charles R. Flint. President, and other officers wore elected, and 16 gentlemen admitted to the active roll. To accommodate the increased membership, a second story is to be added to the present boat-house.

The discussion over the altered prospects of the Swiss export trade in watches goes on with animation in the circles immediately interested. One of the remedies for the overwhelming loss which Switzerland has suffered most frequently referred to is the introduction of American methods and machinery into that country, and there is reason to be lieve that this will be attempted experimentally.

The schooner Emma C. Potter, from Turk's Island, arrived here to-day under a spare mainsail only. Her bulwarks, galley, and standing rigging were carried away, and her boats stove and damaged in a gale. Two of her crew were severely injured.

In the Eighth Assembly District, composed of the Tenth, Eleventh, and part of the Seventeenth Wards, there are three German Republican Associations. Charles Schaper is President of one, William Gellman of another, and George Gaminder of the third. The Schaper organization is identified with the interests of John J. O'Brien, the Republican leader of the district, and the two other organizations are bitterly opposed to it.

John Bryant performed an athletic feat at Union-square on Thursday night which was greatly admired by the spectators. He wheeled "Zeke" Chamberlain, the door-keeper of the Union-Square Theatre, in a hand-barrow around the square in 20 minutes, without accident to the rider.

The ample autobiography and somewhat discursive memorials contained in these two volumes furnish rare materials for the estimate of a woman whose life grew into singular beauty, ripeness, and completeness during many years of great public usefulness. The statement telegraphed from St. Louis, and which appeared in the New-York papers on Wednesday, that 2,000 shares of the Iron Mountain Railroad stock were deposited to secure English bondholders for defaulted Interest is untrue. They were placed in trust to prevent the control of the road from passing from the present managers.

The Senate Finance Committee has voted to report favorably the name of Mr. SCHURZ, in spite of such opposition as was offered. William Rock was arrested today charged with having stolen nearly 15,000 fans, screens, and other fancy articles from the Japanese Bazaar on the Centennial Grounds. At the close of the exhibition the Japanese merchants employed Rock to remove their exhibits. Instead of taking them to the place designated by the owners, he hauled them to his own residence, and until today the Japanese have been unable to find him or their goods.

The mania for marrying titles, with which even divas are attacked, has long prevailed in this theoretically democratic land of ours in the most aggravated and aggravating form.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Seeing an article in the World of this date, headed "The San Francisco Frauds," and claiming that a Republican investigating committee had made a statement of frauds committed in that City at the last election, I do, as a witness of both the registration and polling of votes declare the World's account a garbled and untrue version of the affair.

The Utica Herald of the 7th inst. says: "We congratulate the citizens of Utica on the election of David H. Gaflin for Mayor by a majority of 573. The first dog store in New-York was started About 1845 or 1846 at No. 5 John-street, by Archio and John Greaves, who kept there down to 1559. Then, only a little after them, a man named Moore began selling and trading in doss on Thirtiethstreet, between seventh and Eighth avenues.

Roosevelt, Henry L. Hoguet, and Mrs. Josephine Shaw Lowell--who have instituted the recent examination into the alleged mismanagement of the society's funds.

The Cincinnati Gazette of the 8th inst. says: "The President will tender the post of Minister to France to ex-Gov. Noyes, of Ohio. It is presumed that the way has been made clear for this by the tender of resignation by Mr. Washburne. Ex-Gov. Noyes is a soldier of the war of national preservation, and an efficient campaign orator, well known throughout the State.

The litigation's of the North America, Universal, and Guardian Mutual Life Insurance Companies came up yesterday morning before Justice Dykman, in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, on the application of Mr. John L. Hill to set aside the order of discontinuance in the suit instituted by Mr. H. C. Tremaine.

An officer of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children appeared yesterday in the Court of Special Sessions as a prosecuting witness against a man named John Carr, Whom he charged with having unlawfully made use of his son, a handsome child of 3 years, to procure money by begging.

One of the oldest and most successful houses doing business in the clothing trade in this City is that of Messrs. Rogers, Peet Co., No. 487 Broadway. The firm has been identified with the wholesale trade for about 18 years, but commenced the retail business only three years ago.

As the racing season approaches the note of preparation is heard in all directions. The Spring handicaps have closed, the nomination in the oups are eagerly awaited, and expectation is at a high pitch.

A Well-known gentleman, who boards on Prospect-street, owned a dog that he very much desired to be rid of. On the advice of a friend, he took it to the Central Station and asked if the officers would be so kind as to permanently stop its appetite by dosing it with lead.

A curious incident happened at the last meeting of the Kuedivial Geographical Society. M. De Lessens was explaining the scheme for inundating the Algerian Sahara, and desired to point out something upon the map, when Gen. Stone, the President, galantly drew his word, and presented it to him for the purpose.

Bishop Gilbert Haven is on his way home from Africa, having left Teneriffe, South Africa Feb. 5. It is reported from Rome that Archbishop Howard, cousin of the Duke of Norfolk, has been made a Cardinal.
