The interest in the New-Hampshire contest centres in the election of three Representatives to Congress. The voyage of the ship Fannie Tucker, of Wiscasset, Capt. Joseph M. Roberts. which arrived at this port Thursday, from Calcutta, was somewhat eventful, and came near being attended with tragic results.

Early yesterday morning the large planing mill, on Noble-street, between Eleventh and Twelfth, in Philadelphia, owned by William B. Thomas, and occupied by Turner, Lairsh Co. took fire and was entirely destroyed. The loss on the building is variously estimated at from $20, 000 to $30, 000, on which there is last little insurance, several policies which recently expired not having been renewed.

Dr. Chauncey Giles lectured last evening be fore a large congregation, in the Church of the New-Jerusalem, in Thirty-fifty-street, between park and Lexington avenues, on the subject. "The Claims and Principles of the New Church."

The funerals of Mrs. Ann Spencer and her son Michael, Mrs. Mary Coughlan, and Mrs. Elizabeth Masterson took place yesterday from the respective residences of the deceased.

Daring her absence Lizzie received a call from Maurice Wilroy, a mulatto, aged 16 years, whom she claimed as an acquaintance of three years' standing.

The Paris correspondent of a London newspaper writes: I find a curious piece of news in the Avenir Militaire. There is such a dearth of horses for cavalry remounts, and so much difficulty in procuring them from Austro-Hungary, that the War Office has decided to import a number of horses from the Argentine Republic.

The fire which destroyed the soda factory of J. Monroe Taylor, on Sackett-street, near Ferryplace, Brooklyn, at 1:30 o'clock yesterday morning, was, by the strenuous efforts of the firemen, confined to the building in which it originated, the damage to adjoining structures being caused mainly by the falling walls of the one destroyed.

Gen. GARFIELD'S withdrawal from the Senatorial contest in Ohio will in crease the interestfelt in that struggle. His action (which was taken at the suggestion of the President) is certainly a concession to considerations of public duty.

The people of New-Hampshire win elect tomorrow their Governor, Railroad Commissioner, Legislature, town and county officers, and three members of Congress. They will also vote upon a number of amendments to their Constitution, and should these be ratified, the Legislature chosen (as that body will consequently meet biennially hereafter,) will probably feel called upon to elect a United States Senator to succeed Mr. Cragin at the expiration of his term in 1879.

The funeral of Rev. Henry Robinson Dickon, Pastor of the First Reformed Church, on Joralemon-street, Brooklyn, took place at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon from the church. The casket containing the body was placed in front of the palpit, which was heavily draped in mourning, as were also the galleries and doorways of the church.

An old man named Peter H. Penwell, 65 years of age, killed his wife at Erin Centre, in this county, yesterday evening, by striking her on the head with an axe. He was originally from Huntington, N. J., and they were married five years ago at Toledo.
Napoleon Lapraez, residing at No. 743 Tenth-avenue, was last evening stabbed in the right breast and seriously wounded by George Schuster, of No. 435 West Forty-ninth-street.

Anxious Republicans who have thought that Postmaster-General KEY would consider himself bound to put none but Democrats on guard in the post offices, may cheer up. Mr. KEY has signified his intention of making No changes but those specially needed.

A dispatch from Constantinople published here says according to letters from the provinces the Christian population everywhere is molested, especially in Armenia. The Armenian Patriarch, finding his representation to the Porte of no avail, has tendered his resignation.

The Rochester Union says that Mr. A. B. Lumberton, of that city, has kept a record of the arrival of birds for some years past. In 1872 the first robins were observed there March 28. Wild geese were going north March 29, and snipe were found April 17. That was a backward year. In 1873 robins came March 13, sparrows 17th, blue birds 18th, pigeons 19th, Snipe and woodcock were found at Victor March 28.

The question whether chromos develop or repress a taste for art has been long and vehemently discussed. Opinions differ materially on this point, though there can hardly be two opinions, one would think, in respect to chromos offered as an inducement to newspaper subscribers.

A white walker in the South is as rare as a white crow. I have not seen' a white man wall half a mile since I left New-York. So the foot-path has a sombre sentiment as the track of a down trodden race through fields of labor and secretive woods and cane-brakes. While following its short-cut through a swamp or a pine grove I sometimes met a negro hurrying to town.

The Academy of Music last evening presented a scene seldom witnessed of late years. The Produce Exchange had an unpleasant sensation yesterday in the reported failure and disappearance of Mr. James Kingan, one of its most respected and supposed to be wealthiest members. Mr. Kingan is about 40 years of age, and a native of Ireland. For 20 years past he has been prommently connected with the produce business in this City and the West, and always bore the highest reputation as an honorable merchant.

Very few people will grudge Senator CAMERON the well-earned repose which he secures by his resignation. No act in his long and somewhat checkered political life can be said to have become him so well as the leaving of it.

The San Francisco Chronicle of the 5th inst. relates this surprising story: "Yesterday, James Gibney, who drives hack No. 268, was paid money by several patrons, and upon balancing accounts in the evening he found that by some unaccountable means he was $58 50 ahead, being the possessor of three $20 gold pieces, which some one had given him under the impression that they were three half-dollars.

At a mass-meeting of the citizens held to-night resolutions indorsing the policy of President Hayes were unanimously adopted. Speeches were made by Judges Goakins and Cram and others.

The contest for the Ohio Senatorship has assumed a new form Since the withdrawal of Gen. Garfield, at the President's solicitation, his supporters are distributing themselves among the various candidates, without any concert of action.

The new hospital building erected by the Society of the New-York Hospital, on West Fifteenth-street, is now completely finished and furnished, and will be opened this week for the reception of patients. The old building, which stood on the west side of Broadway, on the ground now occupied by Thomas-street, and bounded by the adjoining streets, has been a landmark for generations.

A summary of the returns to the Bureau of Statistics of the foreign trade of the United States for the mouth of January is just published. The returns show that the imports continued to fall away and the exports to advance, as they have done now for more than a year.

The Navy Department is advised of the departure of the United States man-of-war Swatara from the Portsmouth (Va.) Navy-yard, for Aspinwall. The department is also advised of the honors paid by the United States vessels at Norfolk to the Russian fleet on the 10th inst., on the occasion of the Czar's birthday. The ships were dressed and a salute fired, at the ?? of the Russian Rear-Admiral. .

The work if the State Committee is done. The canvass of the State is complete, and if every voter in New-Hampshire but does his duty as well tomorrow as the work of canvassing has been done, the entire Republican ticket will be elected by a majority that will cut the Democrats to the heart.

The Board of Education, if we understand their action correctly, has deducted temporarily a certain percentage from the salaries of their teachers, and at the same time has presented a bill to the legislature which gives them the power to apply unexpended balances to whatever branch they may think wise, intending thus to make up next Autumn the reduction in the teachers' pay.

A petition signed by Messrs. BELMONT, JEROME, TRAVERS, HUNTER, and others, has been sent to the Legislature, praying for the exemption of the American Jockey Club from the provisions of the law forbidding the selling of pools on elections and horse races.

The Assembly seems to be in earnest on the subject of life insurance. The resolution introduced yesterday for an inquiry into the nature and management of the so-called Chamber of Life Insurance touches a weak point in the system pursued to "protect" the companies against inconvenient legislation or troublesome investigation.

The Raleigh (N. C.) News gives an interesting account of novel legal proceedings growing out of an action against a man because he would not accept office. The next copy of the Supreme Court Reports of North Carolina will contain this case. Which the News says has no precedent in North Carolina.

The Pall Mall Gaett this afternoon, in a leading article, says: "We do not believe the signature of the projected protocol will give any security of peace. Already, if reports from Bosnia are true, forces are at work there to prepare another series of outrages which might precipitate the very war which the protocol intended to prevent.

Between 12 and 1 o'clock this morning an alarm was started on Broadway by shrieks of distress and cries of murder proceeding from the upper story of a tenement-house near Duport-street, and those attracted to the scene were horrified by the sight of a man and woman struggling in a window, the latter attired in her night clothing and the man exerting his strength to throw her out to the payment below.

A Portland dispatch says the present rendezvous of Chief Joseph's band of Nez Perces Indians is located on Joseph's Creek, a tributary of the Grande Ronde River. It is described as a narrow, precipitous gorge, difficult of access, and well protected from any attack which could be made. One hundred men could successfully hold the position against 1,000 soldiers.

The Supreme Court, General Term, yester day rendered a decision in the matter of the application to disbar William H. Gale, an attorney, on account of disreputable practices in connection with the Megarge divorce case. The opinion of the court is written by Judge Danils, who devotes many pages to an elaborate review of the testimony taken before the Referee, who found against Gale.

Mrs. Lydia J. R. Newell, aged 54, the wife of William C. Newell, of No. 7 Jones-St., committed suicide yesterday morning, by hanging herself in her bed-room. Her body was found at 10:30 A. M., suspended from a clothes-rack hook by a stout rope, the noose of which had been deftly knotted.

Fire Marshall Sheldon was engaged yesterday in making an investigation into the mysterious argon case at the liquor store corner of Grand-street and South-fifth-avenue. Although considerable testimony was taken, the only new fact elicited was that Joseph Hancock, the ostensible proprietor of the establishment, had a policy of insurance in the Germania Company for $2,000 on stock and fixtures.

Whether we agree with him or not, at least we must respect his motives. His bitterness of tone is more apparent than real, and if his judgments seem to lack charity, we know, at any rate, that they are sincere.

The troubles that have existed for a long period in the coal regions of this State are being dispelled. Many of the operators having been relieved of their financial embarrassments, are starting their works, and a change for the better is occurring generally throughout the Schuylkill district. The Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company to-day resumed operations at many of the collieries worked in the middle coal fields.

The first meeting of the new Cabinet was held to-day, all the members being present except Secretary of the Navy Thompson, who did not reach Washington until 10 o'clock to-night. The political situation in Louisiana and South Carolina was briefly discussed, but no plan of action was proposed and no conclusions reached.

BOSTON, March 13. About 5:45 o'clock this morning a pistol-shot was heard by the occupants of No. 231 Harrison-avenue, followed by groans, and in two of three minutes another shot. Upon arrival of officers, at the head of the first flight of stairs at No. 284 they found in a dark entry the body of Jacob Hirschfell, a man 60 years of age, whose place of business was another flight up.

The Republicans of New-Hampshire were last night well enough satisfied with the returns of the election. At midnight there seemed to be no doubt that all three members of Congress had been elected by the Republicans, while the Democrats were scarcely accorded a Councilor, and had only three Senators.

The contest for the Ohio Senatorahip has assumed a triangular form, and the nomination promises to be one of the most warmly contested for years. Judge West, Judge Lawrence, Ben Wade, and A. F. Perry, are now regarded as out of the race.

Senator Sherman's letter, resigning his seat, reads thus: WASHINGTON, March 7, 1877. To Hon. Thomas L. Young, Governor of Ohio, Columbus, Ohio : MY DEAR SIR: I respectfully tender to you, and through to the General Assembly of Ohio, my resignation as a Senator from that State.

The St. Paul, (Minn.) Pioneer of the 11th inst. says: "At a special meeting of the Minneapolis Board of Trade, called yesterday morning, a resolution was unanimously adopted cordially approving the policy foreshadowed in President Hayes' inaugural and his selection of Cabinet officers, and requesting our Senators and Representatives to promptly confirm his appointments.

The dispatches given below reveal the fate of Mr. dames Kingan, the produce speculator. He has undoubtedly been murdered. The following dispatch was receive yesterday afternoon by Superintendent Walling:

The Postmaster-General to-day awarded the contract for supplying postage stamps for the ensuing term of four years to the Continental Bank Note Company of New-York City, the present contractors. The contract embraces all the various kinds of postage stamps that are used either by the public or the Government and will require about 720,000,000 stamps to be furnised at each year.

Gen. IGNATIEFF'S talk, as reported by a Paris editor, is not only frank, but warlike. Briefly, this military plenipotentiary declares that Russia will not grant Turkey more than two months' grace to carry out the promised reforms. When this term had expired, the signatory power would no longer be bound to act collectively.

The Board of Directors of the Western Union Telegraph Company held their quarterly meeting yesterday, and declared the usual dividend of 1 1/2 per cent., payable April 19. Mr. Cambridge Livingston was elected a Director in place of Col. W. R. Vermilye, deceased, and Samuel F. Barger, another in place of Cornelius Vanderbilt, deceased. Mr.

After the reception of the reports of the standing committees and the transaction of some routine business, the annual election was held, resulting in the choice of the following officers for the ensuing year;

A Deputy Marshal, accompanied by a squad of soldiers from the camp at Morganton, out in Wilkes County, on Monday last, searching for illicit distilleries, were ambushed by a party of distillers, and due of the soldiers was shot and killed. No arrests were made. During the same raid a man was seen running from the squad, and he was fired on and killed.

BAILEY.--At Quincy ??., March 9, AARON T. BAILEY, aged 26, son or George F. and Sarah A. Bailey, of ??, Conn. Relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend the funeral on Thursday, March 15, at 1 o'clock P. M., at the residence of his wife's father, BenjLynes. No. 8 East 45 ??. Remains to be taken to Green-Wood. Wood.

The renomination of Hon. JOHN JAY KNOX as Controller of the Currency secures to the Government for another term an excellent officer. Mr. KNOX has conducted the affairs of his office with singular intelligence and ability, and his reports have been valuable contributions not only to the discussion of the questions immediately involved in his work, but to economic science.

Judge Lawrence, in Supreme Court, Chamber yesterday reserved his decision on a motion to amend the complaint in the suit of the People, , against the Twenty-third-Street Railway Company. In this action it is sought to restrain the company from building the extensions of the Bleecker-Street Railroad.

At a meeting of the Open Board ot Stockbrokers yesterday, an amendment to the constitution was adopted authorizing the Executive Committee of the board to accept the resignation of members alter their names had been posted for one week, and no valid objection offered.

The steamer City of Havana arrived here this morning from Vera Cruz, and brings the following intelligence from the City of Mexico, under date of March 3: Complaints of fraud and coercion in the elections are received from the interior. The Conservatives were beaten in nearly every district. Mr. Foster, the United States Minister, gave a ball on Washington's birthday.

Crop reports from all parts of the interior show but little change from the prospects two weeks ago all over the State. North of San Francisco Bay grain is in no excellent condition, and an abundant harvest is almost certain.

BALLANTINE--At Newark, N. J., March 15, EDITH AGNES, infant daughter of John H. and Jeannette Ballantine. Friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral on Saturday, 17th inst., at 10 A. M. from the residence of her parents, No. 70 Front-st., Newark. CARLE--On Fourth day. (Wednesday) 14th inst., of on amonia. EDWARD H., son of John Carle, Jr., in the 33d year of his age.

The New-York Oratorio Society gave their third concert this season at Steinway Hall last night. The programme included Bach's "Actus Tragiens" cantata, Brahms' "Requiem," and same numbers from Gluck's "Orpheus." The selections, it will be seen, were of a singularly substantial nature, but the interest of the performance would have been heightened had they been less uniformly somore in toue.

A telegram from Beaver, Utah, dated 7th inst., to the San Francisco papers, says: "In the District Court for the Southern District of Utah the remittitur from the Supreme Court of the Territory was presented commanding the District Court to fix a new date for the execution of John D. Lee. Accordingly, the Court fixed Friday, March 23, as the date for such execution.

From the letter of our correspondent " D," published the other day, supplemented by details procured from one of the School Commissioners and published in another column, it will be perceived that there are two sides to the question of reducing the salaries of school-teachers.

A dispatch from Berlin says: "In each of Prince Bismarck's recent important speeches in the Reichstag he declared that his health was giving way under the exertions to which he was compelled in a great measure by need less antagonism.

In accordance with the provisions of the law passed by the last Legislature to secure tho immediate payment of back wages duo the employes of the New-Jersey Central Railroad, Senator Abbett will make application to the Chancellor to-day for an order to show cause why these Receivcr should not be directed to pay over the money at once.

The Democrats are much distressed over the concourse of office--seekers in Washington. This not unusual gathering they are pleased to call "The Scramble for Place." It happens, however, that there has never been in modem times so few place-hunters at the national capital when the Adminlstration has changed hands.

Last night six Chinamen employed in clearing land near Chico, Butte County, were attacked in their cabin by a gang of whites. Three of the Chinamen were shot dead, a fourth died soon after, and a fifth is be. yond hope of recovery, while a sixth, who was wounded, only escaped by feigning death.

It has been ascertained that the suit for the recovery of $1,000,000, twice the amount of which Jacob Rehm defrauded the Government in connection with the Whisky Ring, will be vigorously pushed by the Government's special counsel, Hon. Emory Storrs.

It is gratifying to find that " the work bepre the Legislature is all in good shape," and that prompt action may fairly be expected on the very important subjects of Municipal and Life Insurance Reform. We have tailed to notice any action with a view of preventing the amendment to the Constitution proposed by the Commission on Municipal Laws.

The betting on the University boat-race between the Oxford and Cambridge crews, which takes place on the Thames on the 24th inst., is 11 to 8 in favor of Oxford. Silver closed to-day at 55 pence per ounce.

A report was received yesterday in this City from Chicago that Mr. Newell of the Lake Shore Railroad Company, alter having agreed to advance passenger rates, had finally backed down tram the arrangement and declined to have anything to do with it at present.

Tho freak of the Democratic leaders in attempting to tie the lands of the new President regarding the troops in Louisiana and South Carolina bids fair to cost the country the expense and annoyance of an extra session of Congress.

The Customs authorities seized 1,500 cigars and 12 bottles of brandy on the German steamer Wieland yesterday. A female child, about three weeks old, was' found last evening in the yard of No. 171 East One Hundred and Twenty-third-street, and was cared for by the Police.

The man who was seen to go over Niagara Falls, at Prospect Park, on the 5th inst., is believed to have been Warren Homer Stone, a school-teacher near Geneva, whose father resides at West Fayette, Seneca County, N. Y. The man left his school on Friday, the 2d inst., saying he was going to visit some relatives.

The Paris correspondent of the London Telegraph writes: "This morning the organ of the late Commune published a thrilling accound of an unsuccessful attempt to escape from New-Calodonla made by nine of the political prisoners there. The only two of the men whose names were prominent ly known in connection with the event of the Communo are Viard and Doboff.

In his inaugural address to the Legislature of Obio. Gov. Young says: "Our distinguished fellow-citizen, Gov. Rutherford B. Haves, having been called to the Presidency of the United States, has resigned the offices of Governor of Obio to assume the duties of his exalted position at Washington.

This morning the store of Mr. Fielder Magruder, in this District, near Benning's Sutlion, on the Baltimore and Potomac Railroad, was destroyed by fire, and the bodies of two men, Epenezer Large and his son John Large, the latter a clerk for Mr. Magruder, both of whom slept in the store, wore discovered in the ruins, burned almost beyond recognition.

In the House of Commons to-day, Mr. Blake moved the second reading of the bill to make provision for the extradition of fugitive criminals. He explained that the bill was to make general provision for the carrying out of the machinery for the extradition of fugitive criminals between the Empire and foreign States and extending it to Canada.

Mrs. Mary Dunham, of Glenville, N. Y., died on Wednesday night at the age of 105 years. William Haight, a respectable citizen of South Oxford, Chenango County, N. Y., was found dead in his sleigh near his home on Wednesday.

Postmaster James bad yesterday in his safe at the Post Office a mass of gold which had just arrived from Sedan, Ind., where it had been recovered from the rains of a burned postal car which was destroyed on the night of the 9th inst. through a celhsion between the eastern-bound Chicago and Buffalo post office train and a freight train.

Two young boys from New-York, giving their names as John Moore, of No. 163 Varickstreet, and Edward Pearsall, of No. 313 West Twenty-ninth-street, aged about 12 years each, were found by Officer Stockes, of the New-Haven Police, near the steam-boat dock in that city, on Wednesday last, and taken to the Police station.

The Board of Education are considering in Committee of the Whole a plan for the better gradation teachers' salaries. The main points have been agreed upon, and the plan will probably come up for final action at the next meeting of the board. The cargo of the British bark Kalema, from Galveston, took fire again last night. The vessel was flooded and the fire extinguished. The cargo is now being discharged. FORT MONROE. March 15.--The brig Lizabel, from Cuba for Boston, is below. It is reported that she last her Captain and some sails, and has four feet of water in her hold.

The third and closing volume of this history has just been issued from the press. Scarcely more than half of the 50 chapters had been completed when the late Vice-President Wilson died. Rev. Samuel Hunt, who assisted Mr. Wilson in preparing the former volumes for the press, completed the one left unfinished by its reputed author.

The remains of an eccentrie and parsimenious individual named John Clark were buried recently at Woolwich. He was 86 years of age, and, although he was repated to be the possessor of a large fortune, he lived to the last in a squakd hovel in the poorest part of Woolwich, where, being a man of education, he devoted himself to the accumiation and study of books, of which he leaves a large were.

Private telegrams from Washington this afternoon reported that Gen. A. J. Vaughan had been appointed Postmaster here. The report spread rapidly throughout the city and was the subject of much comment in business circles, as when it was believed that Tilden was elected a large majority of the business men of the city got up a petition asking him to appoint Gen. Vaughan to that position.

In order to arrive at a just method of distributing the compensation by the Government to the railways performing mail service in the United States, the Post Office Department has required statements to be prepared of the amount of mail matter originating in the offices in large cities, which are to be forwarded to Washington.

The Times, in its financial article to-day, says: "United States railway securities are occupying public attention more than ever before. Suspicion extends more or less to every railway in the Union, sound of unsound. Inquiry shows their finances to be a sealed book.

Stephen S. Jones, editor and proprietor of the Religio-Philosophical Journal, published at No. 127 Fourth-avenue, in this city, was shot dead in his office in the building of that paper, between 1 and 2 o'clock this afternoon. The murderer was a man named Pike, a phronologist, who, with his wife, has had rooms in the building during the past Winter. the past Winter.

There was a largely attended meeting of bondholders of the recognized debt of North Carolina in Room No. 33 at No. 21 Broad-street yesterday afternoon. Mr. andrew Kevan presided. Mr. William J. Best, Receiver of the Mechanics' and Traders' Savings Bank, tor the Executive Committee appointed at a meeting held Dec. 27, read a long report.

During the latter part of Matilda Heron's lifetime she beamed very solicitous about the guardianship of her daughter, Helen Wallaco Stoopel, better known as "Bijon Heron," whom she had trained for the stage. She had asked several of her friends to become the guardian of her daughter, among others A. Oakey Hall, Dr. William H. White, and Mr. James J. Traynor, the Administration Clerk in the Surrogate's office.

The contest is ended, and Mr. Matthews has won contrary to the expectations of nearly everybody but his own supporters. Up to 5 or 6 o'clock to-night there was hardly any outsider who did not concede that Mr. Taft was the coming man. The Matthcews-Packard correspondence, which appeared this morning, had a most adverse influence against Matthews during the early part of the day.

First-Lieut. Constantine Chase, of the Third Artillery, will report to the commanding officer of the artillery school at Fort Monroe for assignment to duty as adjutant of the post and school. First-Lieut. John McGilvray, of the Second Artillery, will report for duty as regimental quartermaster. First-Lieut. Clarence O. Howard, of the Second Artillery.

So far as can be judged, the appointments to minor Federal offices, of which we have a fresh batch daily, are strictly in the line of the President's declared policy regarding the elevation of the standard of the civil service.

It will scarcely be believed that the whole of the session of the Assembly this morning was occupied with the Spinola contemot case. Though the whole matter was of little real importance, yet such is the interest which a personal affair of this kind excites that the Assembly chamber was crowded in a way which it has not been on any other day this session.

A dispatch from Belgrade says: "An officer stationed near Novi Bazar reports that the Turkish forces in that portion of the Empire consist principally of redifs, Poorly clad and generally destitute of underclothing. The rations are bad, and frequently fall altogether."

The war scare seems to be going off a little, and we are for the moment taking an interest in American news. Last night all the evening papers appeared with great lines on their plecards, "The new President of America."

The following cases were argued in the United States Supreme Court yesterday: No. 119--United States vs. Young, Assignee of Collie.--Appeal from the Court of Claims.--This was a motion to dismiss the appeal in the case, the Court of Claims having granted a new trial therein.

On Tuesday last the suit for separation from bed and board brought by Mme, Patti against her husband, the Marquis de Caux, came before the Tribunal of the Seine, A large crowd of persons assembled in the street long before the doors of the Patais de Justice were opened, the amateurs of sensations and scandals being constantly on the qui vive for such occasions.

The Baltimore Guzette in its issue of the 15th inst., thus speaks of its party friends: "Democracy would do well to look the facts of the New-Hampshire election squarely in the face. It is clearly evident that the Democrats did not turn out in fall force, and that so far from defeating the Republicans in that closely divided State they suffered actual loss, and the Republicans made net gains.

FREDERICK DOUGLASS has been appointed and confirmed Marshal of the District of Columbia. The fact that he is of Africau descent and was born in slavery may be commented upon as significant, now that he has received an honorable and lucrative office at the hands of the President of the United States.

At the meeting of tbo Board of Aldermen yesterday, a communication was received from the Park Department stating that the reason why they have not had the lamps around the Franklin statue in Prlnting-house-square lighted, and also lamps erected in front of the Lincoln statue in Union-square, is because the appropriation for such purposes is too small.

The Portland (Me.) Press of the 14th inst. says: "The appointment of Hon. Lot M. Morrill as Collector of this port is an admirable one, and reflects credit alike on our Representative to Congress and the President. Their action will give very general satisfaction to the people of this district and of the whole State.

We may dismiss blue glass from our minds and windows. Even though we admit everything that Gen. PLEASONTON has written concerning the effect of blue glass upon the human and the pig systems, a much more powerful and convenient remedial agent has just been discovered by an intelligent Frenchman.

WADE HAMPTION, telegraphing to Washington in the character of Governor of South Carolina, is reported to say that "he does not wish to be recognized. What he desires," he is good enough to add, "is that the troops shall be removed from the Statehouse, and then the will of the people can be carried out, and carried out peaceably."

War rumors continue to multiply. The Russian policy of delay is certainly bearingfruit. The situation in Constantinople daily grows more grave, and there is every reason to believe that the Ottoman capital is agitated with internal commotions.

The case of Nancy Vedder against Susan G. Vermilye was broght before Judge Lawrence in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, on a motion by the defendant for a stay of all proceedings in the case, because of the plaintiff's alleged weakness ot mind.
There was anotherr meeting of the Cabinet to-day, the matter of making appointments to fill vacancies that will occur before the adjournment of the Senate being the principal business considered.

The journeymen plasterers struck for an increase of wages yesterday, according to their agreement at a meeting on Tuesday evening. Ever since the close of last Summer this class of artisans has been paid from $1 25 to $2 per day's work of 10 hours.

Another collection of paintings, to be sold on the evenings of March 21 and 22, is now to be seen at the Kurtz Gallery, on Madison-square. Mr. Charles L. Frost is known as a collector of good pictures. He sold one collection two or three years ago, and his prospectus says that the present gallery was reserved from that sale.

The brief and interesting report for 1876 of the acting Commissioner of Patents shows that the receipts for the year were $757,985, of which $673,675 was upon applications for patents and kindred operations; the expenditures were $425,930...

The dispatches from New-Brunswick published yesterday morning left no doubt in the minds of Mr. James Kingan's friends in this City that the body found was that gentleman's, and that he had been ?? murdered. Mr. Sinclair of the firm of Kingan Co., (limited,) telegraphed the Coroner at Richibueto a description of Mr. Kingan's person, and an answer was received that it tallied exactly with that of the corpse. .

The deficit in each case is due to the expenses of residing the famine. Loss of revenue from the same cause. and the extraordinary to the starving people.

A fire broke out at midnight Thursday night in the Codman building on Hanover-street, adjoining the American House, Boston. Capt. Grithion, at the Hook and Ladder Company, fell through at floor and was seriously injured. Lewis Rice. the proprietor of the American House died of heart disease superinduced by the excitement of the fire.

The records in the Register's office showed yesterday that conveyances of real estate had been made by Mrs. A. T. Stewart to ex-Judge. Henry Hilton and the Misses Canch. the three sisters of Mrs. Stewart.

The Zoological Gardens at Pesth have just been the scene of a combat worthy of Nero or Elagabulus. The cage tenanted by a lion and lioness happened to the next to that in which dwelt a female leopard, for whom the captive queen of the desert entertained a special hatred.

One of the Leamington policemen lately started that borough by such displays of conviviality that it was found necessary to put a stop for the present at least, to his unseemly proceedings. On Wednesday he was accordingly charged before the magistrates with drunkenness. Martin, such was his name, it appeared from the evidence, was found early that morning by his Inspector drunk on duty.

An atheist he surely was not, for no modern thinker has been more full of the idea of God, and in fact he saw nothing real in the universe but God, so that the Roman Catholic Novalis called him "the God-intoxicated man."
A German Presbyterian congregation has been organized in Philadelphia. A Methodist Sunday-school Congress will be held at St. Louis, April 9-10.

At no time in recent years have the old comedies been played so much among us as during the past season; we even find am bitious dramatic societies of young ladies and gentlemen preparing them for presentation in parlors and town halls.

There is no doubt that the seeming mystery which has been attached to the disappearance of A. Oakey Hall will, before many days, he explained and removed. With the development of a few loading facts which have been discovered, a full and satisfactory account of his movements may be presented to the readers of THE TIMES, which will at one set aside all theories of his having been murdered or of his having committed suicide.

interior of a Japanese theatre resembles our own in many respects, but in many others if quite original and peculiar. The house is similarly planned--that is, with the money-taker's bureau and the vestibule for clogs and cloaks at the door, a gallery running round, in which are private boxes, and the cheapest seats running round the pit.

The first two days of the preliminary examination of the Northampton bank robbers, Scottland Dunlap, have given the public its first clear idea of the method by which the rich "Olu" bank was "cracked." In fact, it wasn't "cracked" at all.

The Russian war-vessels Svetlann, Bogatyr, and Ascold are still lying in the Hudson River, under the Weehawken bluff. Their crews have been hard at work since Friday morning scraping, painting, and burnishing, and the vessels now preseat a neat and orderly appearance, very different from their look when they arrived in port.
An announcement has been published to the effect that the Jewish ecclesiastical authorities, the Beth Din, will in future permit the induction of Christians and others into the Jewish faith.

The Chinese, among their many orignal ideas, have some curious ones on the subject, and doubtless fish now as they did a thousand years ago; and though on the coasts they may have adopted the generally accepted system of working nets, on the waters in the interior of the country they adhere to the methods peculiar to their own nation methods quaint and curious.

It is common to speak of a man who has not succeeded in life, as the expression is, as if non-success were the exception; as if it were a severe reflection upon him; as if it were an evidence of his falling below the average capacity.

Now is the time for the last bargains in the greatest Fair in the world an international exposition halfa-dozen times as large as that which in 1851 set us all thinking the millenium has arrived when Prince Albert's ideas and Paxton's plans were realized in Hyde Park.
The weather of the past week has not been conducive to good feeling on the part of the trainers, but the time is now approaching which will enable the horses to take rapid work.
"Our Boarding House" will be performed at the Park Theatre until further notice. Some curious eyeless fishes have been added to the wonders of the New-York Aquarium.

An interesting suit, in which a ballet dancer sues her husband to obtain a limited divorce, or separation from bed and board, was made the subject of a decision by Judge Lawrence, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday. The action is brought by Jane Portaluppe against Theodore (Pedro) Portalappe.

On the 16th of January the State Senate passed a resolution, introduced by Senator Bixby, instructing the Superintendent of Insurance to obtain from "the various life insurance companies incorporated under the laws of the State of NewYork, a detailed statement showing the amount paid, in salaries, fees, or compensation, or donation to their respective Presidents, Vice-Presidents, Secretaries, medical examiners, attorneys, counselors, and other employes, in the year 1876."

The Faculty of Dartmouth College have decided that hereafter no student shall have the benefit of a scholarship who will not pledge himself to spend no money for liquors, billiards, tobacco, and dancing.

WASHINGTON, March 25.--Notwithstanding the fact that it has been semi-officially announced that no appointments will be made in the diplomatic and consular service until the troubles in South Carolina and Louisiana are settled, those who are seeking to represented the Government in foreign countries have not relaxed their efforts to secure the desired appointments.

LONDON, March 25.--Reuter's dispatch form St. Petersburg controverts the views of the English press relative to the protocol. It says the protocol presupposes conclusion of peace with Montenegro and the demobilization of the Turkish forces.

Most people know that Lyons, France, is the capital of the silk trade, but very few are aware how large that trade is. The principal manufacturers estimate the mean annual value of silk produced at no less than 450,000 francs, or about $88,000,000. One firm alone employs between 3,000 and 4,000 looms, which turn out 1,000 pieces of silk a week.

Palm Sunday was observed yesterday in the Episcopal and Roman Catholic churches of this City with appropriate ceremonies. The day is observed in commomoration of the triumphal entry of our Savious into Jerusalem, when some of the multitude spread their garments and others spread branches of palm in His path, crying "Hosanna to the son of David; blessed be He that cometh in the name of the Lord. Hosanna in the highest."
The commencement exercises of the Woman's Medical College of the New-York Infirmary will take place to-morrow evening at the Union League Hall.

The powerful combination recently formed in the street is understood to make Western Union its main point of attack. Boasts are freely made that the combinatin will force the price far below 60 within a short time.

There remains now apparently but one link needed in the chain of circumstances pointing to Mr. A. Oakey Hall's flight to Europe, to prove that he has taken himself safely out of New-York City, and has not been murdered.

For a man to leave a comfortable home in the North, and its pleasant social life, to migrate to the South, is a hazardous step. For, besides the risk of financial failure, he runs the risk of social discontent in either himself or his wife and family. Nevertheless, there are many who feel impelled to hazard their time and fortune in such an effort.

Ex-President GRANT is reported to have said recently that, when he appointed the Civil Service Commission, he did not contemplate the system of "blackboard examinations" afterward adopted by that body.

Among the great number of special industries created by cotton is the manufacture of oil from the seed. And although this product does not compare in value with sheeting, shirting yarn, thread, and the remarkable variety of other cotton goods, yet the oil has even a closer connection with our bodies than the shirt on our backs. But, not to begin with the end, it is better to describe its manufacture before stating its destination.

LONDON, March 25.--The Observer says the Oxford and Cambridge crews, with their friends, dined together at the St. James Restaurant on Saturday night. The customary toasts were given. For some unexplained reason the affair was kept quite private, and reporters were rigidly excluded.

The British House of Commons is now for the first time in many years complete. The election of the Solicitor-General, who was returned from Launceston the 3d inst., once more makes the membership number no loss than 652, or the same as on March 5, 1874 the date on which the writs for the present Parliament were made returnable. Six seats, however, are vacant, and have been so since 1870.

The correspondent of the London Standard writes from Rome, March 10: "I see that rumors are once again rife in England that the Pope is in an alarming state of health. I am thinking of getting a form of contradiction to such statements lithographed, to save the trouble of writing it over an over again.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: While the lull and calm pending President Hayes' Southern policy is in existence, one who is suffering persecution on account of the stand he took in the last Presidential contest would like to be heard in his own behalf. After the war I thought it our duty, as well as the best policy, to accept the propositions made to us by the Federal Congress.

The Parish will case came up before Judge Barnard, in the Supreme Court, on Saturday, M.A. Fowler appearing for Mrs. Sarah P. Holdridge, in answer to an application for an injunction restraining Mrs. Holdridge from any further proceedings in the Surrogate's Court looking to the further contesting of the will.

--Brentano has for sale the first issue of the new monthly review whose coming has been heralded by the English press. The publishers in London are Henry S. King Co., and the responsible editor is James Knowles. Tennyson has supplied a sonnet by way of preface to this opening number, in which he alludes to the month of March as "this roaring moon of daffodil and crocus."

WASHINGTON, March 25.--Thus far no affirmative responses have been received from the gentlemen invited by the President to serve on the Louisiana Commission, and ex-Gov. Brown remains the only revealed member. The President expects that responses will be received to-morrow.
The racing atmosphere of England is very often so clouded with fraud that the jockey clubs are compelled to resort to stern measures to clear it.

Hord Romo Friganza is Mayor of an Illinois city. The Chicago Greenback folks have nominated a set of candidates for city officers.

On the 3d of last month we gave a minute review of foreign trade for the calendar year 1876, showing a decrease of $64,694,027 in total imports, and an increase of $56,725,312 in total exports, as compared with 1875, the excess of total exports for the year being over $185,000,000.

The agents of the lost steamers George Cromwell and George Washington have received copies of the official reports made by the United States Consul near the scenes of the wrecks to the Secretary of the Treasury. WASHINGTON, March 26.--The Louisiana commission which is being organized by the suggestion of the President and the approval of the Cabinet will certainly not be ready to start until the end of this week. As to its mission and the means which it will employ to reconcile the contending factions represented by Packard and Nicholls, in New-Orleans, there are many conflicting statements.
Prof. William Miller has issued a challenge to Prof. Baner to wrestle at any time within three or four weeks for $200 a side, "most falls in as many hours as he may name."

WASHINGTON, March 26.--Secretaries Schurz and Evarts are still engaged upon the civil service rules, and expect to have them completed, and, if approved, in operation by the 1st of April. Their work upon this subject is expected to result in a few practical rules which will be so elastic as to be applicable to all the departments.

In the United States Circuit Court yesterday morning, Assistant District Attorney Foster informed Judge Benedict that Sherman Reed and Issac Ludlum, of "Reed Co.," and Henry Carr, alias Carson, of "Emory Co.," lottery dealers, who had been charged with mailing lottery circulars, had waived examination before Commissioner Shields, and that "informations," which were substantially indictments, had been filed against them.

The Common Council Chamber was crowded by politicans yesterday, anxious to learn what action the Aldermen would take--now that the board has been organized--in reference to the appointments in their gift. The matter of appointments, however, was not taken up, the board adjourning after a short session until Monday next.

LONG BRANCH, March 26.--A fearful storm has been raging along the Jersey coast for the last 40 hours, sweeping almost everything before it. This evening the steamer Rusland was only a few feet out of water, and was continually being lost from view by immense waves and breakers, covering as high as her smoke-stack. She lies almost parallel with the shore, and seems to be fast in the sand.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 25.--The Call publishes an interesting interview with Capt. John Morse, concerning the Mountain Meadows massacre. The gentleman referred to has figured during many years of an eventful life as a frontiersman, prospector, trapper, and trader, and was in Utah prior to the Mormon settlement, and for many years after it.

On Saturday last a life Senator had to be chosen to fill the vacancy created by the death of Gen. Changarnior, and another curious instance was given of the hazards of political life. The Republicans put forward M. Alfred Andre; his opponent was M. Dupuy de Lome.

The clerical scandal case of Leavitt against McCaffrey came up for an examination yesterday morning at the Fifty-seventh-Street Police Court, before Justice Smith. The friends of the reverend defendant were present in force, but, much to their chagrin, they were excluded from the examination-room, the members of the press and the counsel only being admitted.

Cornell White, of Brooklyn, and it was intended that she should ply between here and Rockaway Beach during the coming Summer.

WASHINGTON, March 26.--The Cabinet was in session for two hours to-day, most of the time being oocupied in discussing the South Carolina case. The subject of discussion was as to the manner in which Hampton and Chamberlain shall be received to make their communications to the President.

It is certain that after a secret Consistory on the 12th inst, he fainted, and had to quit reading the allocution.

A circular from the Controller's office points out the significant face that the appropriations for private charities have increased from $336,412 in 1871 to $967,694 in 1877. This increase is due not so much to new appropriations by the Legislature as to the per capita allowance conferred by special laws, which has, of course, increased with the numbers cared for.

AMSTERDAM, March 28. Rev. Zebulon Phillips, a prominent business man of this place, absconded on the 21st inst., after raising a large amount of money on notes and checks drawn by him in the name of Phillips, Gardiner Co., knit-goods manufacturers, of which firm he was a member. The concern was one of the most extensive factories in this region.

The Louisiana Commission was completed to-day by the acceptance of Wayne MacVeagh, of Pennsylvania, and consists of the gentlemen whose names were announced by THE TIMES dispatch of last night, namely: Ex-Gov. John C. Brown, of Tennessee; John M. Harlan, of Kentucky; Charles B. Lawrence, of Illinois; Joseph R. Hawley, of Connecticut, and Wayne McVeagh, of Pennsylvania.

Judge Blatchford yesterday adjourned the Admiralty branch of the United States District Court for the term. Next month the jury calendar is to be taken up and May and June will be devoted to Admiralty cases.

A careful examination of the scene of the reservoir disaster in Stafford, Conn., to-day bears out the substantial accuracy of the dispatches in THE TIMES of yesterday in regard to the loss of property. The total will scarcely rise over $300,000 and the details of private and town losses are just as printed.

LONG BRANCH, March 28. The steamer Rusland lies in about the same position as yesterday, no further damage being done. The sea has been considerably smoother to-day, and unloading would have been recommended if the weather had been favorable. A blinding snow-storm, with strong north-west winds, prevailed all day, preventing the lighters from coming down.

A boy with two stomachs has recently been produced at Dundee, in Scotland, and his inventor has the effrontery to describe him as an improved style of boy. Useless inventions are numberless, but they do not need the condemnation of public-spirited people, for the obvious reason that they can never be brought into general use.

Pittsburg is fairly entitled to rank as the Sheffield of America. The approaching end of the Lenten season created a speculative feeling in the wholesale meat market during the past few days, and prices have been advanced about 2 cents per pound. Retail prices, however, have not been affected, and remain about the same as last week, with a probability of a rise if the wholesale dealers do not lower their rates. Spring lamb is more plentiful and cheaper.

The State Bank of New-Brunswick, N.J., closed its doors at 1 o'clock P.M. yesterday. There had been rumors of its unsoundness for some time, and depositors had been withdrawing their money freely for several days. Nevertheless, the news of its suspension was a surprise to those not intimately connected with it, and created some consternation and a great deal of gossip.

Down-town merchants are very indignant over the action of the trunk railroads as detailed in yesterday's TIMES. They say that it is a mistaken notion to suppose that they derive any advantage from a railroad war. On the contrary, it enables their sharper neighbors who can succeed in getting better rates to undersell them, and it is consequently injurious to the interests of business in general.

The Treasury now holds $340,123,600 in United State bonds to secure national bank circulation, and $19,323,000 to secure public deposits. At the Anthon Memorial Church, West Forty-eighth-street, the entire chancel was richly adorned with floral designs appropriate to the season. The first representation in this country of "Die Walkure" in its entirety occurred at the Academy of Music last night. The performance commenced at 7:30 o'clock, and did not terminate until 11:45.

PHILADELPHIA, April 2. It was rather a disappointed party of distinguised Philadelphia which assembled in the operating-room of the Western Union Telegraph Company, in the Newyork Mutual Life Insurance Company's building at Tenth and Chestnut streets this evening to hear the telephone concert, as they suppose that to be, which in roality was nothing more than a view of Prof. Frederick...
An Easter entertainment was given last evening to the boys of the Rivington-street Lodging-House.
WADE HAMPTON, we are told, has counseled his friends at Columbia to repress any feeling of exultation which the removal of the troops from the State-house may occasion.

The case of the New-York Juvenile Guardian Society against Henry Roosevelt, H. L. Hoguet, and Josephine Shaw Lowell, came up yesterday in Common Pleas before Judge Charles P. Daly, on a motion to show cause why a prelimiuary injunction should not be granted to prevent the State Charities Aid Association from publishing any reports of its investigations of the society.
A meeting has been called in the Produce Exchange for Friday, to consider the propriety of a change of grade in corn.

HARTFORD, Tuesday, April 3, 1877. The twenty-ninth session of the New-York East Annual Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church will begin at the first Church, in this city, to-morrow. Bishop Jease T. Peck, D.D., presiding.

CINCINNATI, April 3.--The result of the municipal election in this city yesterday has proved an unexpected and very gratifying success for the Republicans. The city for the past four years has been wholly under Democratic rule. The various municipal boards have become filled with incompetent and corrupt men, and it has required continual legislation by the Assembly to protect the city from plunder.

The story of TWEED'S escape and wanderings is quite an interesting addition to the rogues' calendar. It is a pity that we could not have had it in his own unvarnished language, though for the romance of the thing, it is probably as well that it should have passed through the hands of a skillful and appreciative narrator.

KINGSTON, Tuesday, April 3, 1877. The New-York Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church will meet in the Cliff-Street Church at Kingston at 9 o'clock to-morrow morning, and will be called to order by Bishop R.S. Foster, D.D., who has been an honored member of the body for a quarter of a century.
What was announced as a "Flower Party" was given in Delmonico's last evening by the Young Men's Charity Association in aid of the Northeastern Dispensary.

WASHINGTON, April 3. Gen. Hampton intended to leave for home this morning, but, after reading the letter of Gov. Chamberlain, he remained over for the purpose of preparing an address to the country in reply. He mapped out the document, which was to be a complete denial of all the allegations made by his competitor, and had commenced its preparation, when a number of his friends called upon him and strongly advised against it.

A meeting of the Board of Directors of the National Rifle Association was held yesterday afternoon, Judge N.P. Stanton, the President, in the chair. The Treasurer reported a balance on hand of $628 07. On motion of Gen. James B. McQuade, Royal C. Vilas and Major William Este were elected life members of the association.

Adger vs. Adger. Report of Referee confirmed and judement of divorce granted to the plaintiff, with the custody of the children. Gillespie vs. Billings. In this case Mr. Sherman desires to be heard on behalf of Mrs. Julia H. Billings in relation to the appointment of the guardian ad litem.
SIR: Prior to my entering upon the duties of the Presidency there had been stationed, by order of my predecessor, in the State-house at Columbia, S.C., a detachment of United States Infantry.

ALBANY, Tuesday, April 3, 1877. The session of the Assembly this morning has occupied almost wholly by routine business. No debate of any moment took place, and the bills passed were local in their character. The House, at 2 o'clock, adjourned, till evening.

A leaden, watery sky, and 6 o'clock in the morning. I am dashing along Regentstreet in a hansom cab, secured over night at a boat-race premium. It has been raining in torrents since 11. The streets are seas of mud, but troops of laborers are sweeping it into carts and are taking it away.

ALBANY, April 3. The Insurance Committee resumed their investigation at 3:30 o'clock this afternoon.

An influential Georgia newspaper has endeavored to elicit from prominent public men in that part of the South their views respecting the attitude which Southern Democrats should maintain toward the Hayes Administration.

WASHINGTON, April 3. In making appointments, the President has adopted the general rule that where an officer has served for four years in a satisfactory manner, the character of his official services will stand as a recommendation for reappointment, unless there be well-sustained objections of a personal or moral character to the reappointment of the incumbent.

On Monday afternoon last an audacious robbery was committed at the office of the Metropolitan Gas-Light Company, No. 1,501 Broadway, which resulted in the disappearance of three promissory notes, having an aggregate face value of $4,735.

The case of The People ex rel. Charles P. McCarthy, against Calvin G. Lippincott and others, was argued before Judge Donohue, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday. The relator, McCarthy, is the Universalist Minister who was recently suspended from fellowship by the respondents, who are the State Committee on Fellowship, Discipline, and Ordination.

Harper's Weekly of this morning contains the following exceedingly interesting narrative of the flight of William M. Tweed, in December, 1875, and his subsequent wanderings, prepared, it mny be presumed, from statements from his own lips and from his personal diary.
The second annual convention of the American Intercollegiate Athletic Association met at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel yesterday for the purpose of arranging the details for the college games of this year.

A mysterious affair, involving the burning to death of a mulatto girl named Lucy J. Freeman, occurred late on Tuesday night in a brothel kept by a colored woman known as Winters, in West Twenty-seventh-street.

An eminent advocate of civil service reform once said that he did not care if the candidates for the civil service were examined in trigonometry, so long as the examinations were competitive, and were fairly conducted.

KINGSTON, April 4. The 87th Conference of the New-York Methodist-Episcopal Church, Bishop Harris presiding, was called to order in the Clinton-Avenue Church, in this city, at 9 o'clock this morning. Out of a membership of 277 members, about 100 answered to the roll-call. A number of ladies were also present.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 4. The failure of A. Friedlander, a prominent grain operator, was announced today. Mr. Friedlander states that in case he can collect the amounts due him his unsecured indebtedness will be about $600,000.

WASHINGTON, April 4. The Board of Naval Inspectors, recently reorganized, have inspected the new steamer Adams at Norfolk. She will be detained a short time for some necessary alterations, and then leave for Rio Janeiro. The Ranger, now at New-York, will be inspected soon, and then leave for the Asiatic Station.

The case in which the claim agent, George S. Jenkins, is charged by W.H.H. Timmons with having bribed Thomas G. Douglas, a clerk in the Treasury Department, to give him information on which to prosecute claims against the Government for interest on registered bonds, was resumed yesterday afternoon before Commissioner Osborn.
BOSTON, April 4. The New-England Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church opened this morning at the First Methodist Church, at Lynn.

The Emma Mine case was resumed in the United States Circuit Court yesterday, before Judge Wallace, after a fortnight's recess, and the testimony of Joseph E. Clayton, a mining engineer, corroborative of that given by Prof. Silliman, was concluded.
Ex-Congressman H.C. Pratt is among those named for the Republican nomination for Governor of Iowa.
The steamers Batavia and Canada took out, yesterday, 24,591 letters, 217 registered letters, and 44 bags of newspapers.

WASHINGTON, April 4. For the past year there has been a disturbance of the reciprocal relations heretofore existing between this country and Great Britain regarding the registration of labels and trade-marks in the United States Patent Office by the citizens of the latter country.

The property-owners and tax-payers of Southfield, Staten Island, have been for years protesting against what they consider to be an injustice. A few enterprising citizens, as far back as 1868, concluded that the village required an elaborate system of drainage.

Steam routes to Coney Island, approaching the objective point through different streets of Brooklyn, have of late occupied much of the attention of politicians in that city, and at Albany.

A regular meeting of the Board of Education was held yesterday afternoon, President Woodin the chair. The Superintendent of Truaucy reported that during the month of March the total number of cases investigated was 1,228, of which 740 were not classed as truants, leaving 488 truants and non-attendants.

ALBANY, April 4. The Committee on Commerce and Navigation gave a hearing this afternoon to the Quarantine Commissioners on the bill relating to their department which was recommitted to the committee on Monday night.

LONDON, April 4. Following is a description of the woman who accompanied "Sutliffe-Hall." She is about 38 years of age, 5 feet 5 inches in height, has a good figure, dark brown hair, clear complexion, large eyes, and large mouth. She has a wart about two inches below her left ear.

The twenty-ninth annual session of the New-York East Methodist Episcopal Conference began this morning at the Asylum-Street Church, Bishop Jesse T. Peck, D.D., presided, conducting the opening services. He preached a short sermon on the text, "If thine eye be single, thy whole body shall be full of light," and afterward administered the Lord's Supper.

A ray of hope has been thrown upon the situation by the turn affairs have taken in the past few days. If there is a prospect that Europe may escape from the calamity of a general war, there is no nation more ready than Italy to congratulate itself upon so happy a postponement of the risks and inevitable sacrifices which war entails.

The opening of bids for supplying the Government with postal cards for the term of four years from May 1, which was to have taken place at noon to-day, has been indefinitely postponed by order of the Postmaster-General, and a new advertisement will be issued.

A few days since an infant residing inNewark fell from the second-story window to the pavement, and "miraculously escaped injury." A day or two later another infant residing in Newark fell from the second-story window to the pavement, and "miraculously escaped injury."

At the close of business on the Cotton Exchange yesterday afternoon the Secretary announced that a meeting would be held immediately for the purpose of considering the report of the Commission on Cities.
A representation of " Un Ballo in Maschera" was given at the Academy of Music last evening by a company of Italian artists who have passed the Winter in Havana.
WASHINGTON, April 4. There being no session of the Cabinet to-day the President and nearly all the Secretaries were literally besieged by applicants for appointment to office.
WASHINGTON, April 4. The statement published to-day that the President has decided to call the extra session of Congress early in May is not true.

The Consistory of the Collegiate Dutch Reformed Church owns and controls the three churches situated at Lafayette-place and East Fourth-street, Fifth-avenue and Twenty-ninth-street, and Fifthavenue and Forty-eighth-street, besides several missions and a vast amount of real estate devoted to secular purposes.

The narrative of Tweed's escape from his jailers and his subsequent fight as detailed in Harper's Weekly, and copied into the morning papers yesterday, is very interesting reading, but it lacks one essential point truth. It is safe to say that the greater part of the story, so far as it relates to his fight from this City, is pure fiction.

On Monday last, while Mr. Henry R. Winthrop, of No. 35 West Twentieth-street was absent from his residence, a man giving his name as William H. Hall, and representing himself as the "financial agent" of the Presbyterian Hospital, called there and introduced himself to Mrs. Winthrop.

A pretty numerous audience, gathered for the purpose at the Eagle Theatre yesterday evening, shared with Miss. Anna Dickinson her "Crown of Thorns." The piece is the same made known in Boston in May last.

In our obituary column of yesterday, FREDERICK LAHRBUSCH is stated to have died at the age of one hundred and eleven. This announcement is sufficiently startling to invite some comment, not only on this alleged longevity in particular, but on longevity in general.
The bill for the reduction of salaries was passed by the Assembly this morning, after a debate which occupied nearly the whole of the sitting.
At the recent annual distribution of prizes to the successful pupils in the Royal Dublin Siciety's Art Schools, the gold medal was won by Miss. M. Irwin.

CHICAGO, April 4. The whisky rectifiers of the country have entered into a combination calculated to place the price of their products on what may be considered a profitable basis, and, at the same time above suspicion of crookedness.

When Mr. CARLYLE raised his warning voice against the Americanization of England, or, as he preferred to call it, the shooting of a political Niagara, he asked what was to happen after the irrevocable leap over the cataract.

WASHINGTON, April 5. Gov. Chamberain arrived here this evening, and proceeded in the late train to Columbia. He is undecided as to his plans for the future. He says the published statements that he proposes to leave South Carolina, are premature. His action upon reaching Columbia will be determined by circumstances, but he has no intention to resist Hampton.

This was general order day in the Assembly; and in the first committee into which the House resolved itself there were two bills which provoked considerable and rather acrimonious discussion. The first of these was Mr. Bradley's bill one of half a dozen lines only reducing the several department commissions in Brooklyn to single heads.

The case of the Orphan Asylum Society against Benjamin Waterbury, which came up before Judge Robinson, in Common Pleas, Special Term, was decided yesterday. It seems that in May, 1834, the plaintiffs executed to Peter Messilier a lease of the premises Nos. 266 and 267 Broadway, for 21 years.

An extra lecture on India will be delivered by Judge Bick, in Association Hall, on Saturday next, at 4 P.M.

Assistant Foreman Martin Cook, of Engine No. 32, who was the first person to enter the building after the occurrence, made the following statement to a TIMES reporter: "The members of the engine company were all in the house; Fireman Murray and myself were sitting upstairs about 10:30 o'clock, when we were startled by a loud noise, resembling an explosion.

In the United States District Court yesterday, before Judge Blatchford, the trial of a suit was begun in which the Government seeks to confiscate distillery apparatus seized at the vinegar factory of Frederick Fredericks, No. 3 Abattoirplace, on the ground that it was used for the purpose of distilling "crooked" whisky.

The news of the tragedy first reached Port Richmond, Staten Island, the home of Mr. George W. Jewett, about 1 o'clock in the afternoon, and created considerable excitement all along the north shore, where the deceased gentleman was well known and highly respected.

BOSTON, April 5.--John P. Phair will be hanged at the County Jail, in Windsor, Vt., to-morrow, for the murder of Anne Frieze, and the State is confronted with the grave danger of hanging an innocent man. The murder was committed on June 9, 1874, in an outlying portion of the town of Rutland, where Anne Frieze resided.

WASHINGTON, April 5. Secretary Schurz today promulgated an order providing for the investigation and practical determination of questions connected with appointments, removals, and promotions in the various bureaus of his department by means of a Board of Inquiry, to be constituted from time to time, as follows:

ALBANY, April 5. The Railroad Committee will report adversely on Mr. Ecclesine's bill requiring any person suing out an injunction against the Elevated Railroad to file a bond in the sum of $10,000. The committee were afraid that for such a bill to become a law, it being so strongly in favor of the road, would be establishing too dangerous a precedent.

WASHINGTON, April 5. At a Cabinet meeting to-day, Secretary Schurz presented for consideration charges against Gov. Potts of Montana Territory. These charges have been on file for some time, and accuse Gov. Potts of accepting bribes. It is not known what action was taken on the charges, but those familiar with the case express the belief that Potts will be removed. He is from Franklin County, Ohio.

ALBANY, April 5. The Insurance Committee resumed its investigation at 9:30 this morning. Previous to the resumption of the testimony the committee went into executive session, and it is understood that Mr. Floyd Jones made a motion to discontinue the investigation and make a report. What the result of the motion was is unknown.

The conference of railway managers at the Brevoort House adjourned yesterday after arriving at an agreement, of which the following is an official transcript. As will be seen, it makes a difference in eastward-bound freights of 2 and 3 cents per hundred in favor of Philadelphia and Baltimore over New-York.

Major Charles W. Barker, proprietor of "Tattersall's" the well-known auction mart at Broadway and Thirty-ninth-street, died very suddenly on Wednesday night, while traveling to Rochester on business. He is supposed to have died from heart disease, although he showed no symptoms of illness on leaving this City.

The case of Livingston against John H. White came up again yesterday before Judge Donohue in Supreme Court, Chambers, on a motion by Mr. John R. Livingston, to confirm report of Mr. Frederick Smythe, as Referee appointing Mr. Henry S. Van Winkle as Trustee to succeed Mr. John H. White, deceased, in the care of the estate of William Winter.

A rather curious case of larceny was tried by Assistant District Attorney Lyon yesterday, in Part I. of the Court of General Sessions. The facts are as follows: On Dec. 28 last, Joseph Kellner, a baker at Ward's bakery, No. 194 Elizabeth-street, induced a fellow-workman named Max Hoppe to take a drink of what he called whisky from a black bottle. Immediately afterward Hoppe became stupefied, and had to go to bed.

Coroner Ellinger arrived at the place at 2:30 P.M., and took the informal statements of several persons. Capt. Petty informed him that Mr. Dean, when questioned regarding the affair, refused to make any statement whatever, and that Mr. Orville D. Jewett was not in a condition to say anything definite. He, however, admitted to the Captain that there had been "trouble in the firm," but he declined to state its precise nature.

The bill known as the "Woodin Charter," which passed the Assembly last week and was made a special order for to-day in the Senate, was postponed until to-morrow at the request of Mr. Woodin. The bill did not come from the printer's hands in time to allow a thorough examination of the amendments inserted in the Assembly, and hence the postponement.

Mr. Horace White delivered an address last evening, at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel, before the Political Science Association, comparing American with British political institutions. PROVIDENCE, April 5. The remaining town, New-Shoreham, on Block Island, gives Barnaby (Dem.) 40 majority. The Senate is for prohibition, the House adverse to it.

The Children's Carnival, at the Academy of Music, last night, for the benefit of the Homeopathic Western Dispensary, was one of the most delightful and entertaining events ever witnessed in that theatre of so many festivities. The entertainment, which was the first of its kind in this country, was arranged and successfully carried out by Prof. Carl Marwig, whose pupils filled the characters in the various pieces.

LONDON, April 5. A special dispatch from Berlin to the Times says: "The prevailing impression relative to Prince Bismarck's resignation seems less despondent than might have been expected. The opinion of the optimist majority is that there is nothing particular going on just now to retain Prince Bismarck if he requires rest. Politicians, however, attach graver importance to the unforeseen event.

WASHINGTON, April 5. A review of the financial operations of the Government for the nine months ended March 31 last, shows a falling off in the aggregate receipts for the three quarters embraced in that period, of $15,714,932, as compared with the corresponding period of the preceding fiscal year.

HARTFORD, April 6.--The third day's session began with the usual devotional meeting, which included a brief sermon by Rev. John H. Stansbury, of Brooklyn. The routine business was resumed at 9 A.M. when Bishop Peck occupied the chair.

In Part II, of the Court of General Sessions, yesterday, Assistant District Attorney Rollins tried the case of Rev. James H. Humphrey, a colored preacher, indicted for felonious assault. The complainant, a respectable young negro, named Cornelius Pleasance, testified that he lived on the same floor with the prisoner at No. 153 West Thirty-first-street.

The action of the Republican caucus yesterday in postponing the binding of members to vote on the City bills was dictated partially by a desire to wait until it should be seen what expression would come from the public meeting to be held in Chickering Hall to-morrow evening.

In Part I, of the Court of General Sessions, yesterday, Assistant District Attorney Lyon called the case of Jeremiah Callahan, a 'longshoreman, charged with felonious assault, which developed some curious phases of tonement life on the East Side.
Gen. Newton will lecture on "Hell Gate" on Wednesday evening next at Cooper Institute, for the benefit of New-York Central Dispensary.

Rev. Dr. James Ludlow, the Pastor of the Collegiate Reformed Dutch Church, at Fifth-avenue and Forty-eighth-street, whose deposition from his pastorate was sought by the Consistory, sent his resignation to the Consistory on Thursday evening, and it was accepted, several members of the Consistory, however, entering a strong protest against the course pursued by that body in seeking to force Dr. Ludlow to sever his connection with a congregation which earnestly desired to retain him.
Ex-Councilman, Jasper A. Cadmus has been nominated by the Democrats for Mayor of Bayonne, against the present incumbent, Mayor Meigs, who is the Independent's candidate with a Republican indorsement.

WASHINGTON, April 6.--In February, 1875, Congress passed an act creating a commission to survey the Cattaraugus Indian Reservation in New-York, and appropriated $5,000 to pay the necessary expenses. John Manley, of New-York; Joseph Scattergood, of Philadelphia, and Henry Shankland, of Kansas, were appointed the Commissioners under the act, their compensation being fixed at $8 dollars per day and actual expenses.
BOSTON, April 6. The New-England Conference of the Methodist Church reassembled at 8:45 o'clock this morning. There was a prayer-meeting at 8 o'clock, conducted by Rev. I. N. Short, of Franklin.

CHICAGO, April 6. Your representative held an informal talk with ex-President Grant to-day, at Lieut. Gen. Sheridan's head-quarters.
On the the result of the debate in the Lords upon the Eastern question, I said Lord Beaconsfield's defiance of Russia meant war, unless Russia were in earnest in her desire for peace.

The post-mortem examination of Orville D. Jewett's body, at the Chambers-Street Hospital yesterday at noon, resulted in the startling discovery that it had been penetrated by five pistol bullets four small ones, and a fifth corresponding in diameter to the chambers of the large Colt's revolver.

The Associated Executive Committee of Indian Affairs of the Orthodox Friends, were at the Executive Mansion to-day, and presented a memorial on the subject of Indian affairs.

The bill before the Legislature of the State, having reference to the Masonic Hall and Asylum Fund, has been made the subject of much discussion among Freemasons throughout the State, and the result has been the creation of quite a strong opposition to the passage of the bill.

HAVANA, April 6. The Banco San Jose has suspended payment temporarily, being unable to meet the checks presented to-day. The deposits amount to $1,500,000.

The complaint was three years old, so that every opportunity had been afforded in the meantime for the litigating parties to make a settlement if they were so disposed.

BOSTON, April 10. To-day's session was the sixteenth of the New-England Methodist Conference. The Committee on Church building reported that Trustees of churches should hereafter be admonished by their mistakes against contracting debts for church building without scrupulous regard to expense, and the actual needs of church societies and their communities; also that it was the duty of all members of church societies involved in debt to stand by their brethren. MACARONI SOUP. Boil three pounds veal knuckle or scrag, with boes broken, in three quarts of water for three hours; cook one-fourth pound of macaroni, broken into inch pieces, in water in vessel by itself till tender; add little butter just as it is done; strain the meat out of the soup, season to taste; but the macaroni and the water it was cooked in in the soup, let boil once and serve.

ST. LOUIS, April 16. The Coroner's inquest in the Southern Hotel tire case began to-day. WASHINGTON, April 17.--At the Cabinet meeting to-day, which was prolonged nearly three hours, several matters connected with the departments were discussed. No communications from the Louisiana commission were laid before the Cabinet, and Southern affairs were but briefly alluded to.
