THE SURRENDER IN LOUISIANA. To speak of the events at New-Orleans as a " settlement" of the Louisiana question is an obvious perversion of terms. On the 1st day of February of the present year the steam-ship Bavaria, of the Dominion Line, sailed from New-Orleans with a general cargo for Liverpool. LONDON, April 28. The Stock Exchange has been in a very excited condition the past week. Foreign securities fell particularly Russian and Hungarian most heavily on Monday and Tuesday, when the declaration of war was confirmed; the decline deepened on Wednesday, prices rallied very slightly on Thursday, and have since inclined upward. To-day the market, though not much animated, was decidedly better in tone, especially for foreign.

Take one pound of beef, put in a stew-pan with one quart of cold water; let it come to a boil; then pour off the water, place the pan on the stove, break in four eggs, keep constantly stirring, add one teaspoonful of butter, a little pepper, and very little water; on omit the eggs, and add flour instead to thicken the gravy. WASHINGTON, May 9. PostmasterGenernl Key to-day received a letter from Gen. Butler with reference to the removal of his nephew. George H. Butler, from the position of Special Agent of the Post Office Department, to which he was recently appointed upon the recommendation of Samuel S. Cox, of few-York, and Milton Sayler, of Ohio.

The fifty-first annual meeting of the Home Missionary society took place at the Bible House yesterday afternoon, Mr. Charles Demond, of Boston, in the Chair. The meeting was opened with prayer by Rev. Dr. Taylor, of the Broadway Tabernacle. The annual report was next read by the Secretary.

Serious rumors concerning the University of the City of New-York have recently obtained circulation, touching alleged irregularities in the use of its funds and endowments, which are such as to give concern to the numerous friends of the institution.

The unity of the Democratic Party when partisan interests are at stake does not imply absolute agreement as to the course to be pursued. There is no difference between the North and the South in regard to the ulterior objects of the party organization; but there is a marked difference between the immediate purposes which they respectively prefer.

WASHINGTON,May 9. The commission appointed by Postmaster James, of New-York, to inquite into the causes of the late accident at the New-York Post Office Building have reported to Secretary Sherman the result of their investigation and the conclusions arrived at.

LONDON, May 9.--A dispatch to Reuter's Telegram Company from Erzeroum, dated 9 o'clock Tuesday night, says the Russians are surrounding, Soghaule, and concentrating for an attack on Muhktar Pasha's position at Bardiz and Yenikoy.

The sale of the valuable collection of oil and water-color painting, by native and foreign artists, collected by the well-known art connoisseur, Mr. Walter Brown, took place last evening at Association Hall. The attendance was large, including many of the leading art patrons in the City.

WASHINGTON, May 9. The following order has just been issued from the War Department: First The Sixteenth Regiment of Infantry is hereby transferred from the Department of the Gulf to the Department of the Missouri, subject to assignment by the Division Commandor. The Regiment will be sent to Fort Leavenworth in the most couvenient manner, without undue haste, so as to reach its destination in June.
Seventy families have just left Buffalo and vicinity, intending to settle in Beebee County, Minn.

John Powers, a tinsmith, of No.935 Wattsreet, who, on the 4th inst stabbed Catharine McKenua in the arm at No. 38 Cherry-street, was called to the bar of General Sessions yesterday, by Assistant District Attorney Lyon. Powers pleaded guilty, and was sentenced by Judge Gilderaleeve to three years in the State Prison.

The circular which the Porte has just addreesed to the great powers of Europe, in answer to the proclamation of the Czar, shows once more that close and vigorous reasoning which has been the characteristic feature of Ottoman documents ever since the Present difficulties began.

It is evident that the stimulating force exerted by the War in Europe upon onr markets has been checked, though probably not exhausted. Flour of all grades has, on the whole, receded from the prices reached at the close of April. Wheat and corn remain substantially at the same rates, with a downward tendency.

ATHENS, May 9. A vessel which clandestinely left the piraeus was pursued by the Greek ironclad Olga and captured. A crew of 21 was found on bound, all armed. The vessel was brought back and an investigation commenced, which showed that they were pirates and notorious criminals from Asia Minor.

Samuel Morris and William Stant. convicted on April 28 last of mauslaughter in having, on the 1st of February last, caused the death of Charles Bogue,a pencil peddler, were today sentenced, the former to six years and the latter to four years, in the Penitentiary.

LONDON, May 10. A dispatch from Galatz of May 9 says; " Yesterday afternoon two Turkish monitors, supported by the shore batteries at Ghiacet, opened a murderous fire upon the Russian batteries at Ibrail, which replied vigorously. The cannonade lasted three hours. Ibrail was uninjured.

A meeting of the stockholders of the Northern Pacific Railroad was held yesterday at the office of the company, No. 23 Fiftb-avenue, the President, Mr. Charles P. Wright, in the chais Mr. Strike, the Vice.President, made a statement of the prospects of the company, in which he said that the road was in excellent condition throughout, and that it never had been doing a better business than it has done during the present year.

LONDON, May 10.--The Paris correspondent of the Times says: The Russian Telegraph Agency, while declaring that Russia will not reply to Earl Derby's note, publishes a statement which may be considered Russia's informal reply.

It is impossible to convey any definite idea of the financial distress that exists throughout the western regions of the Delaware Valley. For at least three years lumber operators have, as a rule, transacted business at a loss. The Counties of Delaware and Sullivan, in this State, and Wayne, in Pennsylvania, depend, in a great measure, on the lumber products and the tanning interests for prosperity.

WASHINGTON, May 9. 'The Chicago whisky men called on Secretary Sherman today and requested to be heard upon his decision in their cases; but he declined to hear them upon the ground that the decision had been made and announced, and would not be altered.

PHILADELPHIA, May 9. President Hayes, his son, Webb Hayes, and Secretaries Evarts, Sherman, Devens, and McCrary, arrived here at 11 o'clock to-night in Col. Scott's private car, under the escort of the Reception Committee of the Permanent Exhibition Company, comprising Joel J. Bailey, Thomas Cochran, John S. Morron, Isaac H. Clothier, and Thomas S. Ellis.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., May 10. The inquest on the bodies of the Wadesville shaft victims was held in public to-day in Walker's Hall, St. Clair. Willam Hartman testified that he and John Durkin were working in an air course which ran parallel with Lundy's gangway, the scene of tho explosion.

ALBANY, May 10. The Senate Committee on Banking resumed the investagation of charges against Superintendent Ellis this morning, and the charge relative to the Bank of Lansingburg was taken up. The reports of the bank to the Superintendent for 1876 and 1877 were put in evidence.

LONDON, May 10, In the House of Commons this atternoon, Mr. Sullivan withdrew the questions which he gave notice on Tuesday he should ask on Monday next, relative to the intimation of Mr. Cross, the Home Secretary, that England would defend Egypt from interference or attack.

LONDON, May 10. A Vienna dispatch to the Daily Telegraph says the rumored agitation in Servia has been grossly exaggerated. Prince Milan and the Ministers have formally assured Count Andrassy that Servia will not disturb peace.

How small pox first arose among men it is difficult to conjecture. It has been supposed that it may have been originally derived from some disease in the camel. It does not appear to have been known in Europe till the beginning of the eighth century.

WASHINGTON, May 21.--The United States steamer Gettysburg, which has been stationed at Constantinople for several weeks past, subject to the orders of the American Embasay there, has been relieved by the Vandalta, and was at Genoa on the 8th of May for the purpose of having some repairs made to her machinery, after which she will resume her surveying service in the Mediterranean.

Recently the Staten Island ferry-boats have adopted the pleasing practice of racial. Strange to say, among the passengers who are thus provided with a delightful and thoroughly rational sport there are those who are so stupid as to object to racing. They complain that it is contrary to law, and that it is an exceedingly dangerous practice.

ALBANY, May 21.--Gov. Robinson's veto mania has led him into one of those stupid blunders, arising from inexcusable ignorance, that must forever make him the laughing stock of the State, and ought, if he were susceptible of shame, to induce him to resign an office which he has shown himself incapable of filling.
The Old Guard will parade under command of Capt. J.T. Hatfield to-day to commomorate the anniversary of its organization.

The weekly session of the Board of Aldermen yesterday was marked, at intervals, by uproar, laughter, appeals from the decision of the Chair, and a virtual avowal by one of the members that the Common Council was worthless to the City. The trouble arose from two motions one to adjourn and the other to allow a tonsorial artist to erect a barber's pole on the sidewalk in front of his shop.
There is a balance in the City Treasury of $1,115,003.65. During last week $99,033 42 were collected for arrears of taxes.

LOUISVILLE, May 22. The Spring meeting of the Louisville Jockey Club opened to-day. There were 10,000 persons in attendance. The first race, one and one quarter miles dash, was won easily by Janet in 2:12 . Bob Wooley and Elemi sold highest in the pools. There were 12 starters for the Kentucky Derby, one and one-half miles dash.

LONDON, May 22. A Vienna dispatch to the Times says an Odessa letter in the Political Correspodence states that the military commander of the south coast has taken measures to defend Odessa against a coup de main by concentrating there a force of three brigades of infantry, eight sotnias of Cossacks, and six squadrons of light cavalry.

The Financial bill passed the House this morning and now goes to the Governor. The vote upon it was not a, party one exactly, for there were five independent unaded Democrats who voted for the bill; and three Republicans went the other way. The final vote was on the Conference Committee's report, which was a long one, and was printed and placed upon the files some days ago.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 22. Three thousand five hundred Kurds, 12,000 Bashi-Bazouks, 5 infantry battalions, and 7 guns are moving northward from Lake Van to join the Turkish forces at Kara-Kahsa. The Turkish detachment which was expected to attack Bayazid has fallen back toward Lake Van.

The Spring prize meeting of the National Rifle Association will begin to-morrow and continue during the following day. The number of entries in the several matches are quite satisfactory, although the indications are that there will be a less number of competitors from out of town than usual. The prize list is not a very generous one for an organization as large as the National Rifle Association to present to its patrons, ...

PARIS, May 22. The Russian Telegraphic Agency announces that the Emperor of Russia and the Czarewitch start for Ploiesti on the 1st of June. Prince Gortschakoff, Count Adlerberg, and the Minister of War will accompany them. Count Schovvaloff will return to London immediately after the Emperor's departure.

However lucrative farming may once have been, it seems to give but a poor profit now.

PARIS, May 22. Le Temps' Athens special says war between Greece and Turkey is considered invevitable. The Premier, at the opening of the session of the Chamber will deliver a speech tending to war, which, it is thought, will break out in 20 days at the latest.

The farmers and market gardeners of Northern New-Jersey are serioulsy alarmed at the prospect of an invasion of vegetation destroying insects this Summer. From present appearances there is reason to believe that bugs of all kinds, from the seventeen-year locust to the minute insects which rain the current bushes in the family garden, will soon infest the district.
An attempt is to be made to raise pea-nuts in Berks County, Pean. The Ohio Greenback folks have issued a call for a State Convention in Columous, June 6.

The perpetrator of the murder of John Gunser, in his bed at East Wilhamsburg, Long Island, on the night of Sunday, May 13, has not yet been discovered. The inquest was resumed yesterday in Metropolitan Hall, opposite the scene of the murder.

PORTLAND, May 22. The twenty-third annual meeting of R.W. Grand Lodge of Good Templars of the world commenced here this morning, Col. J.J. Hickman, of Louisville, Ky., presiding. About 100 representatives are present, and more are expected. The morning session was occupied by the report of the Committee on Credentials, and the reception and initiation of candidates.

DETROIT, May 22.--The Canadian village of Sandwich, opposite this city, was the scene of an execution at 8 o'clock this morning. On Feb. 26 last, Frederick Appel, a prominent builder of Windsor, Ontario, was shot through the head on the streets of that town, by a discharged workman named Austin Humphrey, who claimed that Appel owed him wages for which be had just asked and received a refusal.

ALBANY, May 22. The whole four hours at the afternoon and evening session of the Assembly seemed to be a continuous fight. All the signs of the near approach of the close of the session were apparent. A resolution for final adjournment on Thursday afternoon at 4 o'clock was passed and sent to the Senate for concurrence.

The report that Mrs. Mary A. La Bau, one of Commodore Vanderbilt's daughters, would contest her father's will, notwithstanding her failure to appear and oppose the instrument after filing her original objections, was verified yesterday by her swearing to new objections drawn by her attorney for the purpose of being filed in the Surrogate's office.

Four men who were fishing in the Sound, off Riker's Island, yesterday afternoon, had their attention attracted to a dark object floating in the water. CHICAGO, May 23. In the Presbyterian General assembly this morning several appeals and overtures of Synods and Presbyteries were received and variously disposed of. The Committee on Church Polity made a report on the establishment of a final Court of Appeals, the substance of which has already been given.

The second trial of Rev. Charles P. McCarthy, of the American Free Church, on charges of immoral and unministerial conduct, preferred by Rev. E.C. Sweetser, was resumed yesterday morning, in the Third Universalist Church, in Bleecker-street.
Julius Lissner, importer of laces at No. 29 Mercer-st., whose failure was announced on Monday, has liabilities of $40,000.

BALTIMORE, May 23. In the Methodist Protestant Convention this morning Pittsburg was selected as the place for holding the next General Conference. Consideration of the report of the Committee on Boundaries was resumed and the report adopted.

PROVIDENCE, May 23. The second day of the annual meeting of the American Baptist Missionary Union opened with devotional services. The officers nominated yesterday were almost unanimously elected. Rev. Dr. Robinson accepted the office of President with a brief address.

The explosion of what is technically known as a "sand blast," which was fired at the foot of East Forty-third street yesterday noon, owing to an undiscovered fissure in the mass of rock in which the drill had been sunk, caused considerable commotion in that neighborhood, although no person was hurt and very little damage was done.

LOUISVILLE, May 23. At the races to-day the weather was fine and the sport interesting. Ten out of the 23 horses nominated started in the Alexander Stakes race half a mile. After numerous false starts the horses were sent off. Milan and Fair Count did not get off.
Robert Thompson was arraigned of the Tombs Police Court yesterday and committed in default of bail, to answer for stealing 200 copies of the Declaration of Independence from Samuel R. Tremble.

Mr. August Belmont has opened his gallery to the public as a means of raising money for the window and family of the late J. Beaufain Irving, an artist whose work has been extensively brought before the American public.

The Alumni of the General Theological Seminary of the Protestant Episcopal Church continued their exercises yesterday. At 7 o'clock A.M. a eucharistic service was held at Calvary Free Chapel, East Twenty-third-street, and immediately afterward the party, comprising many prominent clergymen, enjoyed a social breakfast and reunion at the Gramerch Park Hotel.

BERLIN, May 23. The North German Gazette states that Russia has declared to Tunis that if military or pecuniary aid is redered to the Sultan the Bey must prepare to see his capital bombarded. The Tunis Government is also disquieted by the concentration of a French force on the frontier.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 23.--The Republicans gives the following account of the assassination of James Laws, colored, of East Feliciana: Mr. Dula, of East Feliciana, has reached New-Orleans, and brought with him the coffin that was placed at his door on Saturday, and a bunch of Winchester rifle cartridges which were placed with it.

The Hogeboom Apportionment bill passed the House at the last moments of the morning session. Two Republicans and all the Democrats voted against it. Probably a good many more Republicans would have voted in the negative also, but it is not easy to stand the pressure of party screws when Gov. Alvord is turning them.
It can no longer be denied that there is a large number of people, especially in the Atlantic States, who are obstinately opposed to what is delicately called the remouetization of silver.

It is understood that the managers of the Pennsylvania Railroad have decided upon a reduction of 10 per cent, in the wages and earnings of all their employes, from and after June 1. The order has come from the office in Philadelphia. Superintendent Jackson said yesterday that he had as yet received no official notification, but he was of the belief that such action would be taken.

WASHINGTON May, 23.?Last Saturday a letter of resignation, purporting to be signed by Chief-Justice Lewis, of Washington Territory, was received by the Attorney-General: It was couched in unusual language, and requested the immediate appointment of his successor, in order that, as the letter stated, he might leave the Territory at once.

These dull times are trying to men who have no trade, profession, or vocation. A manufacturing firm in a neighboring city advertised, the other day, for a skilled workman in a specified line of labor.

LONDON, May 23. The Times' Bucharest correspondent says detailed statements of the movements of the Russians are forbidden, but even without this restriction the movements are so silently conducted that it would be exceedingly difficult to report them.

LONDON, May 23. A Vienna dispatch to the Times says Achaschen, to which a remnat of the Ardahan garrison retreated, is on the road toward Olti and Erzeroum. Retreat on Kars was already cut off by the Russians, who blockaded the road at Panisew.

A'direct mail for Porto Rico will be dispatched to-day by the steamer Huntsville. Mary Regan, of No. 52 Mulberry-street, was seriousily scalded yesterday by the upsetting of a kettle of boiling water in her apartments.

The American Metrological Society met yesterday at the Cooper Institute, Prof.F.A.P. Barnard, of Columbia College, in the chair. The principal subject before the meeting was the metric system of weights, measures, and volumes, which is strongly advocated by the society.

Steinmacher, a gold chain manufacturer, who conducted his business at the rear of his residence, committed suicide by swallowing a dose of cyanide of potassium.

The tenth annual meeting of the National Woman Suffrage Association was held yesterday in Masonic Hall. The convention was called to order by Mrs. Isabella Beecher Hooker. Mrs.Olympia Brown made a prayer, and Mrs. Matilda Joslyn Gage read letters of regret from Miss Susan B. Anthony, Mrs. Elizabeth Cady Stanton, and others. Social enjoyment is very much impeded in this country by the want of well-understood rules. Such rules are necessary. The ninety-sixth annual communication of the Grand Lodge of Free and Accepted Masons of the State of New-York, was opened yesterday in the Grand Lodge Room, at the Temple, Twentythird-street and Sixth-avenue, with imposing ceremonies. The musical services were very impressively rendered by a choir of 50 members of St. Cecile Lodge, No. 568, under the leadership of Worshipful Brother Edward Hopkins, Master of St. Cecile, and musical director of the Grand Lodge.

The Democratic managers in Ohio have resolved to hold their convention on the 25th of July, and it is generally conceded that in doing so they were chiefly anxious to "steal a march," with reference to the silver question, on the Republicans, whose convention will be held a week later, and the remarks of such men as Senator THURMAN on this question are interesting.
John Cody, while engaged at the Erie Railway docks, yesterday, was crushed between the bumpers of two cars and dangerously hurt.

The Williamsburg Yacht Club held its annual regatta yesterday. It was the seventh which the club has undertaken, and it was entirely creditable to its management. Especially was this so in respect to the classification of the boats, a matter in which there was no room left for caviling.

The meeting of the advocates of rapid transit, held last night in Chickering Hall, was by far the most notable and significant public assemblage which has been drawn together in this City in the interest of the problem of quick transportation for the Metropolitan population. The audience represented the substance and enterprise of the City, and it responded warmly and emphatically to the sentiments of the speakers.

The General Term of the Court of Common Pleas rendered a decision yesterday in the case of Daniel A. Mowry against the World Mutual Life Insurance Company, which came up on appeal from an order dismissing the complaint. The plaintiff sued to recover $10,000 on a policy of Insurance issued in March, 1868, on the life of Nelson H. Mowry. The latter died April 8, 1868.

CINCINNATI, June 5. Mount Carmel, Ill., which was nearly destroyed by a tornado last evening, is a thriving town of about 3,000 inhabitants, on the Cairo and Vincennes Railroad. The most prominent buildings destroyed were the Courthouse, two newspaper offices, three churches, one of them the finest in Southern Illinois, and two school houses.

One of the most atrocious crimes ever perpetrated in the State of Ohio was the murder in this county, near the village of Gore, and about seven miles from Logan, of Mr. John Weldon, his widowed sister, Mrs. Susan McClurg, and Miss Nanov Hite, a daughter of Mrs. McClurg by a former husband.

The Silver Mountain Mining Company, which is now operating in this City, is undoubtedly swindle of the most impudent character. Though the Police know this, they are prevented by the skill of its managers from interfering with it. These managers are experts in the art of filching from the unwary and, knowing the laws of this State thoroughly, they have organized their company in perfect accordance with them.

NEW-HAVEN, June 24. President Porter delivered his Baccalaureate sermon in Battell Chapel today. He took his text from H. Corinthians, i., 24: "Not for that we have dominior over your faith, but are helpers of your joy; for by faith ye stand."

BOSTON, June 25. About 1,000 persons witnessed the races at Silver Lake this afternoon for single and four-oared shells. The greatest interest centered in the single scull race, from the fact that Morris, Biglin, and Plaisted were advertised to row.

Last week a large fire swept through the thriving City of St. John, New-Brunswick, and laid in ashes the more compact and well-built portion of the place. It is probable that the piles of lumber and the sheds on the wharves added fuel to the flames, and so made powerless the efforts of the firemen.

Four famous oarsmen have been recently brought together who will probably figure most prominently in boarding records before the season is over. Those are George Engelhart, Tom Elliott, John Biglin, and William Maxwell. Each of them has won distinction at the oar, and great things are expected from their united work.

ST. JOHN, June 25. There is nothing new to report to-day. The military and the sailors from the man-of-war Argus have been engaged in knocking down the walls this afternoon. Night patrols have been organized in all the habitable parts of the town. Rebuilding has generally commenced.

A new coalition Ministry has been formed in Athens, which is to unite all parties in a vigorous opposition to Turkey. The popular feeling is generally aroused in favor of Greece taking part in the war. A loan is about being placed, and, no doubt, an army of at least 20,000 men will soon be put on a war-footing.

DETROIT, June 25. The annual election of the Michigan Central Railroad was held here today, and proved to be a very quiet affair. About a dozen persons assembled in the office of the General Freight Agent at 9 o'clock. H.N. Walker, of Detroit, was chosen Chairman, and R.G. Rolston, of New-York, Secretary.

The Eleventh and Seventy-first Regiments proceeded to Creedmoor yesterday for rifle practice in the third and second classes. Each regiment was under its own commander, Col. Vose commanding the Seventy-first, and the Eleventh being under command of Col. Unbekant.

The Brooklyn Ring men made a last desperate struggle yesterday to defeat the confirmation of Gen. James Jourdan as President of the Board of Police and Excise, and met with a crushing defeat. The City Hall was crowded all day by politicians. Threats and entreaties were used lavishly to force the doubtful Domocrats into opposing Gen. Jourdan. The party whip, however, was cracked in vain.

WASHINGTON, June 26.--In a general order just issued the Secretary of War directs that subsistence stores may be sold to an officer on credit on his reccipt for the articles and a certificate that the stores are required for the use of himself and his family, and that he has an unincumbered amount of pay due him sufficient to cover the cost of the articles enumerated.

The receipts from Internal Revenue to-day were $245,747,45, and from Customs, $243,312,48. The President has appointed Gen. W.G.L. Due, of Minnesota, to be Commissioner or Agriculture. The appointment will go into effect on the 1st of July.

NEW-HAVEN, June 27. It has been a proud day for Yale! Never has there been a fuller or more satisfactory gathering of the Alumni. The national character of the college never appeared more conspicuous. At 9:30 I found Alumni Hall packed with a denses mass of black coats.

A bright-looking, pleasant-faced, smiling little girl, with light hair and sparkling brown eyes, was the subject of some proceedings before Judge Donohue, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, in which the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children also bore a part.
A special mail for Porto Rico will be dispatched by the brig Livia Costa, sailing from this port for St. John on the 30th inst.

LEXINGTON, June 27. The annual sale of throughbred yearlings at Woodburn Farm, the estate of A.J. Alexander, took place to-day, and was largely attended by turfmen from all parts of the country, New-York being represented by Messrs. D.D. Withers, G.L. Lorillard, and other wealthy horse-owners.

Modern war is like the kindling of a firework. At first there is nothing but a faint, creeping spark; and then suddenly comes flash on flash, and explosion on explosion, till the eye can barely follow it. The growing of the flame in the East has been long and wearisome; but the explosions are now coming thick and fast.

The nineteenth annual regatta of the Jersey City Yacht Club (for the large boats of the club) was sailed yesterday from a stake-boat anchored east of Bedloe's Island, over a course whose exteme limit is buoy No. 8 off the South-west Spit. Two of the boats, however, the Mignon and Spray, sailed a shorter course by agreement, turning the hospital ship and leaving it to port.

HANOVER, June 27. The inauguration of Samuel Co. Bartlett, as President of Dartmouth, was imposing. The town is crowded with visitors, and the hotels and private houses are overflowing with guests of the Alumni.

A jovial party of brokers thronged the steam-boat Virginia Seymour, that left the dock at the foot of Wall-street, at 3:30 yesterday afternoon, for the Harlem River. The purpose of the party was to witness a race between two four-cared gig crews of the Stock Exchange Rowing Association.

The murder of a little girl by her insane father has given rise to great excitement in the village of Breslau, Long Island. The man's name is Michael Gorgen. He is a German, and once resided with his wife and three children at No. 247 Wallabout-street, Williamsburg.

Yesterday morning Gov. HARTRANFT, of Pennsylvania, rose somewhat subsequent to the lark's usual hour, and after grasping the fact that he was in Providence, and had on the previous evening attended a meeting of the Grand Army of the Republic, immediately became a prey to melancholy.

ST. JOHN, June 27. Affairs are gradually settling down. The excitement is all over, and everybody is at work. Hundreds are employed at the ruins, and handsome structures are to be erected at once. Stores are open, and business has been resumed all around.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 27. Dispatches from Lewiston, Idaho, report the state of affairs to the 26th inst. Renegade Indians are joining the hostiles, and runners have been sent to the Palouse, Spokan, Columbia River, and Uamtilla tribes, who, they claimed would join them, and they would then clear the whole country from Boise City to Lewiston.

BOSTON, June 27. At an early hour the morning the hall and corridors of the Brunswick Hotel were lively with visitors and guests, brilliant with the uniforms of staff officers, and busy with the preparations for the departure of President Hayes, who, was to attend the Commencement exercises at Harvard College.

Early yesterday morning a fatal accident occurred at the new building of the Brooklyn Sugar Refining Company, at the foot of South First-street, Brooklyn, E.D. The building is 11 stories in height, or 147 feet, and was nearly ready for occupancy.

About 10 o'clock on Tuesday night the storehouse and bake-shop at Sing Sing Prison was discovered to be on fire. A summons for aid was sent by the Warden to the Fire Department of the village, the members of which failed to respond promptly to the call.

SOHENECTADY, June 27. To-day is a galaday, and it is the eighty-first commencement of Union College. The great event of the day is the Chandellor's Oration by George William Curtis, of New-York.

DES MONIES, June 27. The Republican State Convention held here to-day, although at times it threatened to be turbulent, was more harmonious in its results than was generally expected. It was the largest convention ever held in the State, and the first in which every county was represented.
